description: In this course, we explore some more advanced features of PowerPoint 2016. We start with digging deeper into PowerPoint options, customizing the interface, and exploring advanced file properties including accessibility and security. Other topics include modifying the all-important slide master, adding external content such as Excel data into slides as linked objects, inserting audio and video, and collaborating with others both online and offline. We finish up the series with customizing the delivery of presentations with custom shows, hyperlinks, and Zoom.

We finish up the series with customizing the delivery of presentations with custom shows, hyperlinks, and Zoom.
name: Advanced PowerPoint 2016
subtitle: Presentation application to create slide shows

episodes.description: In this course, we explore some more advanced features of PowerPoint 2016. We start with digging deeper into PowerPoint options, customizing the interface, and exploring advanced file properties including accessibility and security. Other topics include modifying the all-important slide master, adding external content such as Excel data into slides as linked objects, inserting audio and video, and collaborating with others both online and offline. We finish up the series with customizing the delivery of presentations with custom shows, hyperlinks, and Zoom.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:06.021
[NOISE] Hey,
did you guys enjoy that PowerPoint 2016?

2
00:00:06.021 --> 00:00:11.264
Great news, cuz we got another course
coming your way, Advanced PowerPoint 2016.

3
00:00:11.264 --> 00:00:14.590
Here to tell us all about it and what
we're gonna learn is Miss Vonne Smith.

4
00:00:14.590 --> 00:00:15.396
>> Thank you Mike.

5
00:00:15.396 --> 00:00:19.292
Yes, we're going to be taking a little bit
deeper dive into PowerPoint and really

6
00:00:19.292 --> 00:00:22.972
start getting into the nitty gritties of
PowerPoint and what it can do for us.

7
00:00:22.972 --> 00:00:25.850
So we're just gonna take it a little
bit further in this series.

8
00:00:25.850 --> 00:00:28.722
We're gonna get into
customizing our interface.

9
00:00:28.722 --> 00:00:31.242
We're gonna be creating our own
tabs in the ribbon this time,

10
00:00:31.242 --> 00:00:33.060
instead of using whatever is there.

11
00:00:33.060 --> 00:00:36.128
We're going to also be talking
about advanced file features, or

12
00:00:36.128 --> 00:00:38.986
advanced file properties such
as inspecting our document.

13
00:00:38.986 --> 00:00:42.933
And talking about some important features
like accessibility, and making sure that

14
00:00:42.933 --> 00:00:47.230
we have the PowerPoint ready for the right
audience that we're going to be serving.

15
00:00:47.230 --> 00:00:49.340
We're also gonna be jumping
into that Slide Master,

16
00:00:49.340 --> 00:00:52.240
the all important Slide Master
that rules them all, and

17
00:00:52.240 --> 00:00:56.860
being able to control that, and be able to
really get a good handle on our PowerPoint

18
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:59.480
presentation the way that
we want it to be formatted.

19
00:00:59.480 --> 00:01:04.070
We're also going to be linking to external
content from other Office products and

20
00:01:04.070 --> 00:01:08.060
be able to link and embed content
into the PowerPoint presentation.

21
00:01:08.060 --> 00:01:10.290
We're also gonna be adding some video and
some audio.

22
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:14.092
So you'll be seeing more of Fuego and
Bishop, [LAUGH] and our wonderful cats.

23
00:01:14.092 --> 00:01:17.419
We're also gonna be talking about
different ways that we're going to be

24
00:01:17.419 --> 00:01:19.339
collaborating with other individuals.

25
00:01:19.339 --> 00:01:24.077
And with some of the neat new features
that they have in the cloud using

26
00:01:24.077 --> 00:01:26.779
OneDrive and our use of Office 365.

27
00:01:26.779 --> 00:01:30.343
Then we're gonna finish it all up with
how we can create some custom PowerPoint

28
00:01:30.343 --> 00:01:31.159
presentations.

29
00:01:31.159 --> 00:01:34.376
And how we can customize what
slides we're going to be using, and

30
00:01:34.376 --> 00:01:38.354
be able to really utilize the different
ways that we can hyperlink to things, and

31
00:01:38.354 --> 00:01:42.035
create action buttons, and
have for our different audiences.

32
00:01:42.035 --> 00:01:46.033
So if that sounds like fun, I hope you
stay tuned, and let's jump right in.

33
00:01:46.033 --> 00:01:49.544
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike look at the ways that you can customize the user interface in PowerPoint. They demonstrate configuring general settings and account settings. They also look at settings for proofing and saving presentations.
episodes.title: Customize PowerPoint Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.946
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.946 --> 00:00:08.189
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.189 --> 00:00:12.390
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.390 --> 00:00:15.616
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.616 --> 00:00:20.196
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our Advanced Powerpoint 2016.

6
00:00:20.196 --> 00:00:21.959
And specifically in this episode,

7
00:00:21.959 --> 00:00:26.300
we're gonna be looking at customizing
the user interface within PowerPoint.

8
00:00:26.300 --> 00:00:30.100
And here to show us the way and all the
cool things we can do is Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:30.990
Welcome back, Vonne.

10
00:00:30.990 --> 00:00:33.160
>> Thank you, thank you so
much for having me.

11
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:35.710
So just as Mike said, we're going
to be customizing our interface.

12
00:00:35.710 --> 00:00:38.710
We're gonna start
personalizing our PowerPoint.

13
00:00:38.710 --> 00:00:42.850
Because once we start getting familiar
with where everything is in the ribbon,

14
00:00:42.850 --> 00:00:44.730
and how do we add content,

15
00:00:44.730 --> 00:00:47.660
there's going to be certain things
that is gonna pop along the way.

16
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:51.670
Of like, I really wish it would stop doing
that or I don't want this to happen, or

17
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:53.550
can I make this a little different, and

18
00:00:53.550 --> 00:00:57.070
that's where going through the PowerPoint
options is going to be really helpful.

19
00:00:57.070 --> 00:00:59.780
Now there's a lot of options in here,
I mean we could probably be talking about

20
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:04.670
this for hours really if we went over
every single one in like minute detail.

21
00:01:04.670 --> 00:01:07.737
But what we're gonna do is gonna go
through each one of the categories and

22
00:01:07.737 --> 00:01:10.470
then I'm going to point
out some of the ones that

23
00:01:10.470 --> 00:01:12.590
I've found that have been helpful to me.

24
00:01:12.590 --> 00:01:14.870
So I would like to share that with you,
and

25
00:01:14.870 --> 00:01:18.410
maybe just at least get you familiar
with what is even in there.

26
00:01:18.410 --> 00:01:21.370
So later down the road,
it's like I think that's a check box,

27
00:01:21.370 --> 00:01:24.910
an option, and if I turn that off,
it would stop doing whatever it is,

28
00:01:24.910 --> 00:01:27.180
it's not making me happy right now.

29
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:30.050
And this is actually for
all of your products.

30
00:01:30.050 --> 00:01:33.260
So, you can do the same thing in Word and
Excel.

31
00:01:33.260 --> 00:01:36.890
It's kind of nice to at least go
through them and point them out.

32
00:01:36.890 --> 00:01:40.600
So, I have a file that we're
gonna go ahead and just open so

33
00:01:40.600 --> 00:01:43.460
we can get PowerPoint ready to go.

34
00:01:43.460 --> 00:01:47.210
So we're gonna bring back to stars
of the first PowerPoint show.

35
00:01:47.210 --> 00:01:49.030
We're gonna bring back the kitties.

36
00:01:49.030 --> 00:01:51.550
So we're gonna bring up learn PowerPoint.

37
00:01:51.550 --> 00:01:55.365
So, if you haven't watched
the PowerPoint 2016 series,

38
00:01:55.365 --> 00:01:59.165
they're a lot too and
they're gonna be in this one too.

39
00:01:59.165 --> 00:02:00.073
[LAUGH]
>> Fuego and

40
00:02:00.073 --> 00:02:03.267
Bishop are gonna be worldwide
stars at this point.

41
00:02:03.267 --> 00:02:04.441
>> [LAUGH] Yes, I know.

42
00:02:04.441 --> 00:02:06.732
That means probably gonna
get to their head and

43
00:02:06.732 --> 00:02:09.217
he's gonna just lay around
more than he does now.

44
00:02:09.217 --> 00:02:14.910
So we're gonna go ahead and
go to File > Options.

45
00:02:14.910 --> 00:02:17.360
And we're gonna go through our
different PowerPoint options.

46
00:02:17.360 --> 00:02:21.430
Now on that first series that we did on
PowerPoint, we did come here a few times

47
00:02:21.430 --> 00:02:25.560
when we were doing our editing,
our auto-correct options.

48
00:02:25.560 --> 00:02:29.509
And we were also here when we were
customizing our quick-access toolbar.

49
00:02:29.509 --> 00:02:31.980
And that's really all we
really went through it.

50
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:35.303
So we're gonna just take a few moments
to go through each one of these, so

51
00:02:35.303 --> 00:02:37.056
we're gonna start with the general.

52
00:02:37.056 --> 00:02:42.031
And here we have some different options
in our user interface the mini toolbar.

53
00:02:42.031 --> 00:02:45.520
I will tell you that this thing,
was it 2003?

54
00:02:45.520 --> 00:02:47.450
>> I believe it is when it first came out,
yes.

55
00:02:47.450 --> 00:02:50.910
>> Yeah, and I don't know about you,
but I couldn't stand that thing.

56
00:02:50.910 --> 00:02:54.071
>> When it first came out it annoyed
the heck out of me, and I've learned in

57
00:02:54.071 --> 00:02:57.485
options how to turn it off, but since
then I've actually turned it back on.

58
00:02:57.485 --> 00:03:00.259
>> Yeah, that was the first thing I
would do at any computer that I was at,

59
00:03:00.259 --> 00:03:02.813
I would go into the options and
I would turn off the main toolbar.

60
00:03:02.813 --> 00:03:06.830
But now I like it,
I think it's quite helpful.

61
00:03:06.830 --> 00:03:09.550
So if you're not familiar,
like what are you even talking about?

62
00:03:09.550 --> 00:03:10.520
What is the mini tool bar?

63
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:14.780
Cuz I don't know if I actually even
really pointed it out so blatantly,

64
00:03:14.780 --> 00:03:17.690
if you wanna say, in the first series.

65
00:03:17.690 --> 00:03:22.765
The mini toolbar comes up when you
have selected items in your text or

66
00:03:22.765 --> 00:03:25.260
maybe a picture, or in a table.

67
00:03:25.260 --> 00:03:28.700
So, I'm gonna go ahead and
select the word layout.

68
00:03:28.700 --> 00:03:30.976
And you can see it's right there,

69
00:03:30.976 --> 00:03:35.615
that little toolbar that pops up
right away as soon as I select it.

70
00:03:35.615 --> 00:03:39.243
It's going to give me some quick
options to format my text.

71
00:03:39.243 --> 00:03:44.520
If I had selected a column in a table or
an image or something else,

72
00:03:44.520 --> 00:03:48.490
your mini toolbar is going to change
depending on whatever you have selected.

73
00:03:48.490 --> 00:03:50.280
>> So, it's context sensitive.

74
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:54.130
It's gonna give you the most
commonly used tools

75
00:03:54.130 --> 00:03:56.195
depending on what it is you have selected.

76
00:03:56.195 --> 00:03:58.470
>> Yes, and
it's nice because it's right there.

77
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:00.860
Now you're saying, well,
it's right there on the Home tab.

78
00:04:00.860 --> 00:04:02.340
But what if you aren't on the Home tab.

79
00:04:02.340 --> 00:04:06.150
What if I was over on say,
the Transitions tab, and

80
00:04:06.150 --> 00:04:08.410
I wanted to just quickly make that bold.

81
00:04:08.410 --> 00:04:10.740
Well, if that wasn't there,
I'd have to go back up to the Home,

82
00:04:10.740 --> 00:04:14.110
I'd have to click on the end, so
it's just two or three more clicks,

83
00:04:14.110 --> 00:04:17.510
but you reduce a couple clicks, and
it's gonna make your life a lot easier.

84
00:04:17.510 --> 00:04:22.470
So I've come to really appreciate
the mini toolbar for its purpose.

85
00:04:22.470 --> 00:04:24.590
And good job, Microsoft.

86
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:26.750
>> Yes, [LAUGH].
>> So I like it now.

87
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:29.893
Another thing while I'm here,
the live previews that we have,

88
00:04:29.893 --> 00:04:32.758
as I go back to the home tab and
not stay on the mini toolbar.

89
00:04:32.758 --> 00:04:35.740
If I have the live previews that show me,

90
00:04:35.740 --> 00:04:41.020
before I actually commit to something
of what it's going to look like.

91
00:04:41.020 --> 00:04:44.340
Now that is a feature they they started
adding, I believe, in 2003 as well.

92
00:04:44.340 --> 00:04:47.650
Really great, and
it's always on by default.

93
00:04:47.650 --> 00:04:51.240
But back over here in our File > Options.

94
00:04:51.240 --> 00:04:53.270
>> Actually before you do that,
can you show that one more time,

95
00:04:53.270 --> 00:04:55.300
I think the word was
behind your drop down.

96
00:04:55.300 --> 00:04:57.120
Maybe select something out
in the middle of the slide.

97
00:04:57.120 --> 00:04:58.160
>> How about we do this.

98
00:04:58.160 --> 00:05:02.880
Why don't we take this one, and
we'll go ahead and go over to Format.

99
00:05:02.880 --> 00:05:06.120
And you can see that right there, perfect.

100
00:05:06.120 --> 00:05:10.665
So you can see that while I'm hovering
over the different colors and

101
00:05:10.665 --> 00:05:13.456
formatting the fill color of this shape,

102
00:05:13.456 --> 00:05:17.778
it's letting me see what it's
going to look like before I do it.

103
00:05:17.778 --> 00:05:22.950
And that is live preview and
I love it, I think its fantastic.

104
00:05:22.950 --> 00:05:26.070
>> Yeah, I know I've stared at it and gone
okay what color would look good here and

105
00:05:26.070 --> 00:05:28.149
it's a pain to click on it and
then go back and look and

106
00:05:28.149 --> 00:05:29.692
click on another one go back and look.

107
00:05:29.692 --> 00:05:33.640
This way you can kind of see as your
hovering over there really quick.

108
00:05:33.640 --> 00:05:36.230
But, it does have some down sides,
doesn't it?

109
00:05:36.230 --> 00:05:39.080
>> It does, if you have a computer
that maybe is a little bit older,

110
00:05:39.080 --> 00:05:44.897
doesn't have as fast of a GPU or graphical
processing, is that, okay thank you.

111
00:05:44.897 --> 00:05:48.343
[LAUGH] I know the letters and
I start saying it, and I'm like,

112
00:05:48.343 --> 00:05:50.873
I'm pretty sure that's what it stands for.

113
00:05:50.873 --> 00:05:52.789
Your memory, your RAM,

114
00:05:52.789 --> 00:05:57.898
basically if your computer doesn't
have the oomph to support it,

115
00:05:57.898 --> 00:06:03.207
it can maybe bog down your program,
it's not gonna perform as fast.

116
00:06:03.207 --> 00:06:07.601
So that's something that does take a lot
of it, so if you want to turn off that

117
00:06:07.601 --> 00:06:12.365
live preview, you can do so and
it might make it a little easier for you.

118
00:06:12.365 --> 00:06:15.715
But it was a huge feature
when it first came out.

119
00:06:15.715 --> 00:06:19.219
So if your computer can handle it,
I would say don't turn it off.

120
00:06:19.219 --> 00:06:23.933
But back in to PowerPoint, sorry I had
already gone back to my File tab and

121
00:06:23.933 --> 00:06:25.810
gone back to my Options.

122
00:06:25.810 --> 00:06:30.425
You can see that those two check boxes
there is what we're talking about.

123
00:06:30.425 --> 00:06:32.275
Keeping the mini toolbar on or off, and

124
00:06:32.275 --> 00:06:35.175
having the live preview enabled or
disabled.

125
00:06:35.175 --> 00:06:40.165
If we keep on going down our list,
personalize your copy of Microsoft Office.

126
00:06:40.165 --> 00:06:42.185
This is what your computer is named of.

127
00:06:42.185 --> 00:06:45.255
When I actually created this Machine and

128
00:06:45.255 --> 00:06:48.775
it's this version of
Windows on my computer,

129
00:06:48.775 --> 00:06:53.855
I named it VonnePC because it's my PC,
version on this computer.

130
00:06:53.855 --> 00:06:55.021
[LAUGH]
>> It is funny that

131
00:06:55.021 --> 00:06:58.336
it actually pulls your computer name and
not your username.

132
00:06:58.336 --> 00:07:01.180
Which would make more sense maybe,
at least to me.

133
00:07:01.180 --> 00:07:03.190
>> I always thought that too,
when I started this.

134
00:07:03.190 --> 00:07:05.500
I'm like,
why isn't it named Justin Timberlake?

135
00:07:05.500 --> 00:07:09.700
Because that's the account that
I'm using in my Office 365, and

136
00:07:09.700 --> 00:07:12.790
that's what everything I'm signed in to,
and that is it but

137
00:07:12.790 --> 00:07:14.300
it really does pull from
your computer name.

138
00:07:14.300 --> 00:07:18.892
So if you have some weird thing in there,
it could be that whoever installed your

139
00:07:18.892 --> 00:07:22.524
operating system on your computer
within your organization,

140
00:07:22.524 --> 00:07:24.525
it might have some weird numbers.

141
00:07:24.525 --> 00:07:29.495
Because that's how your IT department has
cataloged how this version of Windows

142
00:07:29.495 --> 00:07:33.450
is installed on all the machines
in your office or what have you.

143
00:07:33.450 --> 00:07:37.300
So that could be different,
and that's okay, but

144
00:07:37.300 --> 00:07:39.180
at least you know that that's
what's going to pull off.

145
00:07:39.180 --> 00:07:44.100
Now when I start doing collaboration and
reviewing with my PowerPoint with other

146
00:07:44.100 --> 00:07:48.370
people, which we'll be using in future
episodes, it does use your username there.

147
00:07:48.370 --> 00:07:50.873
It will use Justin Timberlake,
it won't say VonnePC.

148
00:07:50.873 --> 00:07:54.222
But I have seen in the past at
least before Microsoft Office,

149
00:07:54.222 --> 00:07:58.228
the whole subscription base in the cloud,
it would use that and whatever

150
00:07:58.228 --> 00:08:02.453
the initials you would have if you were
doing track changes and everything.

151
00:08:02.453 --> 00:08:06.013
More in Word than PowerPoint, cuz you
don't have track changes in PowerPoint.

152
00:08:06.013 --> 00:08:08.839
But it would pull from
whatever you have here so

153
00:08:08.839 --> 00:08:13.114
if you wanted to have it say something or
display differently when your

154
00:08:13.114 --> 00:08:18.660
sharing documents then you could go ahead
and customize it with this right here.

155
00:08:18.660 --> 00:08:23.598
I'm gonna take a quick skip down to the
bottom, the enable PowerPoint designer.

156
00:08:23.598 --> 00:08:27.836
This is where in that first PowerPoint
series where this thing is super awesome,

157
00:08:27.836 --> 00:08:29.410
I love PowerPoint Designer.

158
00:08:29.410 --> 00:08:32.450
That's where it's going to give you those
designing tips when you start inserting

159
00:08:32.450 --> 00:08:38.320
multiple images and brings it off to the
right hand pane to give you the options.

160
00:08:38.320 --> 00:08:41.890
It is something that you do have
to have an Office 365 account,

161
00:08:41.890 --> 00:08:46.720
so if you don't have that then you
probably won't even have that option.

162
00:08:46.720 --> 00:08:48.841
So, that was the kind
of contingency on that.

163
00:08:48.841 --> 00:08:52.088
And I would always enable it
cuz I think it's fantastic.

164
00:08:52.088 --> 00:08:58.746
So, if you don't see it, the whole Office
365 subscription would be a reason why.

165
00:08:58.746 --> 00:09:01.650
>> Interesting, so some of these
settings are dependent on whether

166
00:09:01.650 --> 00:09:04.740
you are logged in to
your Office 365 account?

167
00:09:04.740 --> 00:09:06.139
>> Yes, definitely.

168
00:09:06.139 --> 00:09:10.487
The designer is one of them and another
one that we're going to take a look

169
00:09:10.487 --> 00:09:14.450
at is the customization of our
background and our Office theme.

170
00:09:14.450 --> 00:09:17.896
So up here in the personalize your coffee?

171
00:09:17.896 --> 00:09:20.047
[LAUGH]
>> I do like personalized coffee.

172
00:09:20.047 --> 00:09:20.547
[LAUGH]
>> Maybe I need some more coffee.

173
00:09:20.547 --> 00:09:21.894
Probably not actually, that'd be bad.

174
00:09:21.894 --> 00:09:23.595
Bad, you don't want to see it.

175
00:09:23.595 --> 00:09:25.916
So I have Office background and

And I've thought it throws people off.

403
00:21:08.440 --> 00:21:10.340
>> Right.
>> It's really because like what did I do?

404
00:21:10.340 --> 00:21:12.491
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, so the drag and drop text,

405
00:21:12.491 --> 00:21:13.658
while it can be handy,

406
00:21:13.658 --> 00:21:17.664
if that's what you wanted to do, if it's
a little bit of a distraction to me.

407
00:21:17.664 --> 00:21:19.781
>> It's the same with me,
I mean I can cut and paste, so

408
00:21:19.781 --> 00:21:21.528
I've got my keyboard shortcuts for that.

409
00:21:21.528 --> 00:21:25.406
So if I need to move it, I've got other
ways of moving it, this one seems to

410
00:21:25.406 --> 00:21:28.993
happen when I'm not really trying to
do that so I like to turn it off.

411
00:21:28.993 --> 00:21:34.240
But I do know people who love that feature
and they're constantly rearranging text.

412
00:21:34.240 --> 00:21:38.069
And it's a little bit easier than having
to cut it, select it, copy it, paste it,

413
00:21:38.069 --> 00:21:38.962
things like that.

414
00:21:38.962 --> 00:21:40.099
So some people might like it.

415
00:21:40.099 --> 00:21:42.169
>> Yeah, it has its merits.

416
00:21:42.169 --> 00:21:44.770
It's just something that I
don't particularly like.

417
00:21:44.770 --> 00:21:46.220
And that's, of course,
the whole reason for

418
00:21:46.220 --> 00:21:50.360
this episode is to show all the different
things that happen within your PowerPoint

419
00:21:50.360 --> 00:21:52.380
environment that you might not like.

420
00:21:52.380 --> 00:21:58.200
So let's go back over to our account
cuz we went over the advanced.

421
00:21:58.200 --> 00:22:01.730
The two parts that I wanted
to show you was the undo and

422
00:22:01.730 --> 00:22:03.305
the allow text to be dragged and dropped.

423
00:22:03.305 --> 00:22:06.380
But you can see,
there's a lot of other ones,

424
00:22:06.380 --> 00:22:09.630
like in a slide show,
like the pop up toolbar.

425
00:22:09.630 --> 00:22:12.740
I like the pop up toolbar,
I don't want that to really go away.

426
00:22:12.740 --> 00:22:17.350
Maybe you don't want it to end with
the black slide, you can turn it off,

427
00:22:17.350 --> 00:22:18.930
>> We were talking about that in our

428
00:22:18.930 --> 00:22:23.270
previous series, where if you're giving a
presentation and the only light is coming

429
00:22:23.270 --> 00:22:28.210
from your presentation in a dark
auditorium, if the last slide

430
00:22:28.210 --> 00:22:32.600
is black and you click to it everything
gets dark, people trip, whatever.

431
00:22:32.600 --> 00:22:35.261
Whereas if the last slide was a little
bit lighter, at least there might be some

432
00:22:35.261 --> 00:22:37.257
light in there before somebody
can find the light switch.

433
00:22:37.257 --> 00:22:39.536
>> Yeah, that's a perfect example
because I'm thinking like,

434
00:22:39.536 --> 00:22:41.264
why would you not want to
end with a black slide?

435
00:22:41.264 --> 00:22:42.366
That's just what PowerPoint does.

436
00:22:42.366 --> 00:22:43.637
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well,

437
00:22:43.637 --> 00:22:44.680
you can make it a bit different so.

438
00:22:44.680 --> 00:22:45.600
>> [LAUGH] Right.

439
00:22:45.600 --> 00:22:49.280
>> So that's a great example of why
you might want to not have that done.

440
00:22:49.280 --> 00:22:51.000
>> All right, well,
Vonne, I tell you what,

441
00:22:51.000 --> 00:22:55.120
I know we've got a lot of additional
options to go through there, but

442
00:22:55.120 --> 00:22:57.930
unfortunately we're out of time for
this particular episode.

443
00:22:57.930 --> 00:23:00.400
So why don't we stop there,
and we'll do a part two.

444
00:23:00.400 --> 00:23:03.480
We'll come back and we'll continue to
go through the rest of these options.

445
00:23:03.480 --> 00:23:04.110
Sound like a plan?

446
00:23:04.110 --> 00:23:05.060
>> Sounds great.

447
00:23:05.060 --> 00:23:07.540
All right, well, ladies and gentleman,
you heard it, we're gonna call it here.

448
00:23:07.540 --> 00:23:10.490
We're gonna come back with a part
two on customizing your interface.

449
00:23:10.490 --> 00:23:13.760
But for now, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

450
00:23:13.760 --> 00:23:14.420
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

451
00:23:14.420 --> 00:23:15.545
>> And we'll see you next time.

452
00:23:17.251 --> 00:23:23.103
[MUSIC]

453
00:23:23.103 --> 00:23:26.075
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike continue their exploration of the customization options in PowerPoint. They look at the advanced options and how to customize the ribbons and quick access toolbar. They also discuss the various options in the Trust Center Settings.
episodes.title: Customize PowerPoint Interface Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:02.131
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.131 --> 00:00:06.140
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.140 --> 00:00:08.252
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.252 --> 00:00:12.296
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.296 --> 00:00:15.290
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.290 --> 00:00:20.239
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our advanced PowerPoint 2016.

7
00:00:20.239 --> 00:00:23.753
And in this episode, we're actually
continuing our thought process on,

8
00:00:23.753 --> 00:00:27.610
this is a part two and customizing
your user interface within PowerPoint.

9
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:29.470
So if you missed that first part,
make sure you go back and

10
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:32.210

jump right back into it and

11
00:00:32.210 --> 00:00:34.870
here to show us the way is none
other than Ms. Vonne Smith.

12
00:00:34.870 --> 00:00:35.562
Welcome back Vonne.

13
00:00:35.562 --> 00:00:39.392
>> Hello, yes,
we left off on the advanced options,

14
00:00:39.392 --> 00:00:42.609
I believe within our PowerPoint options.

15
00:00:42.609 --> 00:00:46.260
So like he said, let's just go ahead and
jump right back in And get started.

16
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:48.705
I actually didn't even
really change the screen.

17
00:00:48.705 --> 00:00:51.187
[LAUGH]
>> We're back here on Advanced and

18
00:00:51.187 --> 00:00:54.892
we had left off just going
over our black slide, right?

19
00:00:54.892 --> 00:00:55.543
>> Yup that's right.

20
00:00:55.543 --> 00:00:59.103
Yes, and while we're here I do have
a when printing this document,

21
00:00:59.103 --> 00:01:02.787
it might be one of those things that
every time you go to print you always

22
00:01:02.787 --> 00:01:06.860
have to change the settings back to
whatever you had wanted it to be.

23
00:01:06.860 --> 00:01:10.490
So you could go ahead and create your
default printing settings of like,

24
00:01:10.490 --> 00:01:11.620
you always want it to print the notes.

25
00:01:11.620 --> 00:01:15.910
And you always want it to print
in grayscale and not in color.

26
00:01:15.910 --> 00:01:18.170
So you could go ahead and set that there.

27
00:01:18.170 --> 00:01:21.021
It does have the use most
recently used print settings.

28
00:01:21.021 --> 00:01:24.101
So if you keep using the same ones,
you might not ever notice that,

29
00:01:24.101 --> 00:01:27.900
because it's always back to the way you
had it last, because that is the default.

30
00:01:27.900 --> 00:01:30.623
But while I was here,
I figured I'd point it out to you guys.

31
00:01:30.623 --> 00:01:31.890
>> Fantastic Vonne, all right.

32
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:33.770
So what's next on our list of options?

33
00:01:33.770 --> 00:01:36.080
>> Yes,
we'll keep going down that left hand side.

34
00:01:36.080 --> 00:01:39.752
And we're gonna get into the customizing
the ribbon and the quick access tool bar.

35
00:01:39.752 --> 00:01:45.420
I've kinda put those both together
because they are used for

36
00:01:45.420 --> 00:01:50.690
creating and customizing all the different
commands that are on that top area

37
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:52.550
of your PowerPoint environment.

38
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:56.430
And a quick access toolbar is
somewhere where we went in the first

39
00:01:56.430 --> 00:01:57.390
series of PowerPoint.

40
00:01:57.390 --> 00:02:01.670
Where we went ahead added some
of those buttons along the top.

41
00:02:01.670 --> 00:02:04.200
And let's just quickly show
us that this right here,

42
00:02:04.200 --> 00:02:05.950
this is a quick access toolbar.

43
00:02:05.950 --> 00:02:10.119
So we went into the Customizing settings.

44
00:02:10.119 --> 00:02:13.419
From the actual toolbar itself,
we went into more commands and

45
00:02:13.419 --> 00:02:15.856
it automatically brought
us to this section.

46
00:02:15.856 --> 00:02:17.597
Where we could go ahead and

47
00:02:17.597 --> 00:02:21.801
add commands that we wanted to
quickly access on that toolbar.

48
00:02:21.801 --> 00:02:25.218
And, if you wanted to add say,
check spelling, that,

49
00:02:25.218 --> 00:02:28.144
I was just making sure
that wasn't over there.

50
00:02:28.144 --> 00:02:32.053
[LAUGH] You wanted to add the check
the spelling because I always need to run

51
00:02:32.053 --> 00:02:33.830
a spell check.

52
00:02:33.830 --> 00:02:39.310
You have to remember what tab
on the ribbon that command

53
00:02:39.310 --> 00:02:44.960
lives in cuz it might not be in
the popular commands that is

54
00:02:44.960 --> 00:02:48.870
showed by default in the customizing
quick access tool bar.

55
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:50.206
So up at the top.

56
00:02:50.206 --> 00:02:52.710
You can go into which tab or

57
00:02:52.710 --> 00:02:56.330
where it actually appears within your
ribbon, and then you can go from there.

58
00:02:56.330 --> 00:03:00.390
I know that the spell check is in

59
00:03:00.390 --> 00:03:06.190
the review tab and where is that?

60
00:03:06.190 --> 00:03:08.490
There it is.
[LAUGH] My God, I don't see it.

61
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:11.420
I know it's on the review
come on find the review.

62
00:03:11.420 --> 00:03:16.510
So you can go down here to the spell
check which is right there,

63
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:21.320
check spelling and I can add it and then
it moves over to my quick access toolbar.

64
00:03:21.320 --> 00:03:25.966
And the other thing that you can point out
is that if you wanted to reset this cuz

65
00:03:25.966 --> 00:03:28.628
maybe you've gotten this all kinda crazy.

66
00:03:28.628 --> 00:03:31.410
And you're like can we just
go back to where it was,

67
00:03:31.410 --> 00:03:33.730
cuz I don't remember where I began.

68
00:03:33.730 --> 00:03:37.340
You can always go ahead and
click that Reset down here.

69
00:03:37.340 --> 00:03:39.920
And notice that it is going
to give us the option for

70
00:03:39.920 --> 00:03:44.330
Reset only the quick access tool bar,
or reset all customizations.

71
00:03:44.330 --> 00:03:47.430
And that could be for
any of the things with your ribbons,

72
00:03:47.430 --> 00:03:48.590
which we're going to get into.

73
00:03:48.590 --> 00:03:50.399
And it's gonna remove everything.

74
00:03:50.399 --> 00:03:54.228
So you do to be a little careful
about which one do I want to do?

75
00:03:54.228 --> 00:03:59.156
So if I say only the Quick Access
Toolbar It will go ahead and

76
00:03:59.156 --> 00:04:04.597
bring it back to where the default
options were on that toolbar.

77
00:04:04.597 --> 00:04:08.545
>> I also like the option that that filter
list up there, there was one option for

78
00:04:08.545 --> 00:04:09.358
all commands.

79
00:04:09.358 --> 00:04:14.440
Cuz like me, I can't remember, was
the spell check on the review ribbon or

80
00:04:14.440 --> 00:04:17.682
on the developer ribbon or
where the heck is it?

81
00:04:17.682 --> 00:04:18.940
I just go to all commands.

82
00:04:18.940 --> 00:04:20.000
And it's a longer list.

83
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:21.870
It takes me a little
longer to get through, but

84
00:04:21.870 --> 00:04:24.460
at least I know it's in there
somewhere cuz that's all commands.

85
00:04:24.460 --> 00:04:25.831
>> Yes, good point.

86
00:04:25.831 --> 00:04:28.100
When I was going I was like,
so it's on the review tab.

87
00:04:28.100 --> 00:04:28.971
I know it's on the review.

88
00:04:28.971 --> 00:04:29.832
And then I started questioning myself.

89
00:04:29.832 --> 00:04:31.130
Is it on the review tab?

90
00:04:31.130 --> 00:04:32.080
I dont remember.

91
00:04:32.080 --> 00:04:36.611
So yes, all commands is a great
way to just show everything and

92
00:04:36.611 --> 00:04:40.195
you can figure out what
you want to do from there.

93
00:04:40.195 --> 00:04:43.785
So quick access toolbar,
nice little toolbar at the beginning,

94
00:04:43.785 --> 00:04:44.839
at the beginning?

95
00:04:44.839 --> 00:04:45.393
At the top.

96
00:04:45.393 --> 00:04:46.102
>> [LAUGH].

97
00:04:46.102 --> 00:04:46.968
>> Of our environment.

98
00:04:46.968 --> 00:04:48.583
But what about those ribbons?

99
00:04:48.583 --> 00:04:49.924
Let's go ahead and cancel.

100
00:04:49.924 --> 00:04:53.164
You have your regular
tabs across the ribbons,

101
00:04:53.164 --> 00:04:56.571
your Home, your Transitions,
your slide show.

102
00:04:56.571 --> 00:05:01.780
If you wanted to, you could create
your own tab on the ribbon.

103
00:05:01.780 --> 00:05:05.300
And that's where you can put
everything that you've ever used.

104
00:05:05.300 --> 00:05:07.608
Maybe you're always using
the same commands, and

105
00:05:07.608 --> 00:05:11.431
instead of switching back and forth, back
and forth through each one of these tabs?

106
00:05:11.431 --> 00:05:16.430
You can make your own, and
put any command that you want on that.

107
00:05:16.430 --> 00:05:20.476
Pointing out here on your tabs on your
ribbons, you do have your groups, so

108
00:05:20.476 --> 00:05:23.961
you see in the insert you have tables,
images, illustration.

109
00:05:23.961 --> 00:05:28.291
And I'm just pointing that out because
once we get into the customizing of it,

110
00:05:28.291 --> 00:05:31.831
you do have to know that that
terminology of what is a group name,

111
00:05:31.831 --> 00:05:33.100
before you get going.

112
00:05:33.100 --> 00:05:35.000
So let's go back over here to File,

113
00:05:35.000 --> 00:05:38.940
and let's go into Options again,
we're gonna go into Customize.

114
00:05:38.940 --> 00:05:41.030
The not the, yes customize the ribbon.

115
00:05:41.030 --> 00:05:43.113
Sorry like which one are we doing?

116
00:05:43.113 --> 00:05:44.840
Yes, we are doing the ribbon.

117
00:05:44.840 --> 00:05:50.410
Over here you have, these are the main
tabs that are across the ribbon and

118
00:05:50.410 --> 00:05:54.600
if you wanted to add your own
tab down here at the bottom,

119
00:05:54.600 --> 00:05:57.680
you could see that you have new tabs.

120
00:05:57.680 --> 00:05:58.970
So we're going to create that.

121
00:06:00.725 --> 00:06:04.845
And it adds in a new tab,
now I have the new tab here and

122
00:06:04.845 --> 00:06:06.919
I have the new group here.

123
00:06:06.919 --> 00:06:12.030
If you wanted to rename the group or
the tab, you just gonna make

124
00:06:12.030 --> 00:06:18.280
sure that your on the right part within
this list to click the Rename button.

125
00:06:18.280 --> 00:06:20.950
So I'm gonna start at the tab first.

126
00:06:20.950 --> 00:06:25.243
And I'm going to click the Rename, and
I'm just gonna go ahead and put in Vonne,

127
00:06:25.243 --> 00:06:26.390
cuz that's who I am.

128
00:06:26.390 --> 00:06:28.301
And I want all of my stuff there.

129
00:06:28.301 --> 00:06:30.990
So I'll click OK, and I've renamed that.

130
00:06:30.990 --> 00:06:33.505
And if I go ahead and
start trying to put in a command, so

131
00:06:33.505 --> 00:06:37.445
over here on the left-hand side, you could
see that I have all the different commands

132
00:06:37.445 --> 00:06:41.221
that are in there, and then that's maybe
where we should go to that all commands so

133
00:06:41.221 --> 00:06:43.281
I can just have the entire list there for
me.

134
00:06:43.281 --> 00:06:44.854
And everything is in here.

135
00:06:44.854 --> 00:06:47.665
And I'm just gonna randomly pick things,
honestly.

136
00:06:47.665 --> 00:06:49.770
>> [LAUGH]
>> So maybe I want the arrow down,

137
00:06:49.770 --> 00:06:52.829
cuz that's definitely a shape
that I'm gonna be doing.

138
00:06:52.829 --> 00:06:54.745
I can click on that and click on the Add.

139
00:06:54.745 --> 00:06:56.860
You will get a warning, though.

140
00:06:56.860 --> 00:06:59.110
That's why I wanted to point
out that group, it says,

141
00:06:59.110 --> 00:07:03.230
I can't add a command
unless I'm in a group.

142
00:07:03.230 --> 00:07:07.900
Because I was on the tab name, so you need
to make sure you're in that group, and

143
00:07:07.900 --> 00:07:10.995
it always defaults to giving
you at least one group.

144
00:07:10.995 --> 00:07:14.512
So make sure that you're there before
you start adding the commands.

145
00:07:14.512 --> 00:07:16.220
So now that I'm here.

146
00:07:16.220 --> 00:07:22.530
I click here on the command that I want to
then add, and it goes into that new group.

147
00:07:22.530 --> 00:07:26.952
I can go ahead and rename this,
and I can name it My Commands.

148
00:07:26.952 --> 00:07:30.250
I can give it a little picture,
how about a little piggy.

149
00:07:30.250 --> 00:07:32.572
It doesn't really show up but,
[LAUGH] It's there.

150
00:07:32.572 --> 00:07:34.521
And so now I could go ahead and

151
00:07:34.521 --> 00:07:38.510
then keep on adding as many
different options that I want.

152
00:07:39.520 --> 00:07:41.130
Again I'm randomly picking.

153
00:07:41.130 --> 00:07:44.772
I'm just click, click, click, I don't
know really know what I'm even adding.

154
00:07:44.772 --> 00:07:47.880
[LAUGH] But I'm just trying to show
you that you can find the command.

155
00:07:47.880 --> 00:07:51.179
You add it over in your
group within your ribbon.

156
00:07:51.179 --> 00:07:55.737
If you wanted to add another
group to start organizing things,

157
00:07:55.737 --> 00:08:01.413
you're more than welcome to add another
group and then continue to add More and

158
00:08:01.413 --> 00:08:06.315
more commands and then once you got
your commands you can go ahead and

159
00:08:06.315 --> 00:08:09.422
click OK, and across there, there it is.

160
00:08:09.422 --> 00:08:13.680
All of my buttons, all of my commands
I wanted in my own special tab on

161
00:08:13.680 --> 00:08:17.221
the ribbon I'm feeling very,
very special right now.

162
00:08:17.221 --> 00:08:18.404
>> It does make you feel yeah.

163
00:08:18.404 --> 00:08:20.190
>> It's my PowerPoint.
>> It does make you feel special,

164
00:08:20.190 --> 00:08:23.160
the other cool thing I think we should
point out is you can take commands that

165
00:08:23.160 --> 00:08:25.630
are already on other
ribbons it's not like they.

166
00:08:27.025 --> 00:08:29.685
If they're in on another ribbon,
you can't add them.

167
00:08:29.685 --> 00:08:32.155
Cuz there's lots of commands,
there's a few commands,

168
00:08:32.155 --> 00:08:34.475
if I can speak,
from the Home Ribbon that I use a lot.

169
00:08:34.475 --> 00:08:37.185
There's a few from
the Developer I use a lot.

170
00:08:37.185 --> 00:08:39.468
And I have to go back and
forth between those Ribbons.

171
00:08:39.468 --> 00:08:42.965
But now I can create my own ribbon,
put all the tools in one place, and

172
00:08:42.965 --> 00:08:45.452
pretty much live right
there on that one ribbon.

173
00:08:45.452 --> 00:08:47.665
It's great that Microsoft
gave us the ability.

174
00:08:47.665 --> 00:08:50.915
Cuz remember in 2003 when it first came

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike work with the Slide Master in PowerPoint. They demonstrate working with the Slide Master to customize design templates. They also look at creating a custom template that can be reused.

00:27:37.120 --> 00:27:41.430
The other thing that you can do,

But what you could also do is

I like to keep it in there because,

so if you open up PowerPoint and

00:29:06.440 --> 00:29:10.132
If you put it somewhere else, it might

612
00:29:10.132 --> 00:29:12.913
>> Yeah, you could put it somewhere else,
but to me,

613
00:29:12.913 --> 00:29:14.673
put it where it goes by default.

614
00:29:14.673 --> 00:29:20.245
And if you really want it to go and make

615
00:29:20.245 --> 00:29:25.118
but keep the themes wherever your

616
00:29:25.118 --> 00:29:31.775
So, why don't we go ahead and name this,
"pink template" good a name as any.

617
00:29:31.775 --> 00:29:32.530
>> Mm-hm.

618
00:29:32.530 --> 00:29:34.740

00:29:42.888 --> 00:29:47.866
[LAUGH]
>> So now I've got, if I should be able to

00:29:52.020 --> 00:29:55.190
But anyways, I have it over,

You know where it's at?

[LAUGH] It's over here in custom.

00:29:58.259 --> 00:29:59.196

00:29:59.196 --> 00:30:02.419
>> On my Custom Office Template, oops,

And there's my other one.

00:30:03.456 --> 00:30:04.059
>> Yeah.

631

>> So if you saw when I did the File,
Save As.

632
00:30:06.013 --> 00:30:07.594
>> Uh-huh.
>> I was playing around.

00:30:07.594 --> 00:30:11.880
And so now I have the ITPro.TV theme,

00:30:11.880 --> 00:30:14.590
Sorry, I forgot that doesn't

The design themes show up on that one,

So once I go ahead and do that,

It started a new presentation

646

So, another point of where if you'd

Like you always are gonna start off

00:30:53.140 --> 00:30:55.660
You can always save that,

And you can move forward with that.

And that's a great launching point for

In a specific way that you want it to be.

653
00:31:05.670 --> 00:31:07.530

00:31:49.488 --> 00:31:52.803
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike continue to work with the master templates in PowerPoint. They demonstrate how to work with the Notes Master and the Handout Master. Similar to the Slide Master, they show how to customize and save these templates.
episodes.title: Slide Masters Part 2

Rather than the ones that,

What if I wanted that to

79

You could come in here and format, you do

No, if you have a full presentation and

just like we had done

We went ahead and

So I don't want you to think I

00:04:25.360 --> 00:04:26.860

00:04:26.860 --> 00:04:28.040
It can be either one.

And, so now I have the view of our notes.

97

00:04:50.710 --> 00:04:52.530
I want to make the slide

00:04:52.530 --> 00:04:55.460
So, I'm going to take this and

100
00:04:55.460 --> 00:04:56.970
Or make the slide a little smaller.

101
00:04:56.970 --> 00:04:57.790
I can move this.

102
00:04:57.790 --> 00:05:00.360
Maybe I want this up in
the upper right hand corner.

103
00:05:00.360 --> 00:05:01.490
You can move where the header.

I don't know if I really wanna take

cuz headers kinda [CROSSTALK]

00:05:05.220 --> 00:05:06.196

107
00:05:06.196 --> 00:05:07.695
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But you can.

00:05:07.695 --> 00:05:09.125
You can do whatever you want honestly.

109
00:05:09.125 --> 00:05:11.600
And I would keep the footers and

00:05:11.600 --> 00:05:13.830

00:05:13.830 --> 00:05:17.425
Maybe move this box up,

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike look at several ways to link and embed objects in PowerPoint. They demonstrate linking and embedding objects from Word and Excel, and compare and contrast the two methods. They also look at adding hyperlinks to a presentation.
episodes.title: Link and Embed External Content
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.078
Welcome to ITPro.TV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.078 --> 00:00:08.257
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.257 --> 00:00:12.115
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.115 --> 00:00:15.565
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:15.565 --> 00:00:20.040
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our advanced PowerPoint 2016.

6
00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:23.391
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna learn how to link and

7
00:00:23.391 --> 00:00:26.610
embed external content into
our PowerPoint presentation.

8
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:29.470
Here to show us how to do all
of that is Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:29.470 --> 00:00:30.410
Welcome back Vonne.

10
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:31.290
>> Thank you Mike.

11
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:34.310
Yes, we're going to be taking
information from other places and

12
00:00:34.310 --> 00:00:35.800
putting it into PowerPoint.

13
00:00:35.800 --> 00:00:40.390
Now this isn't just a copy and paste, like
I'm going to copy something out of a Word

14
00:00:40.390 --> 00:00:43.780
document and then put in the text
into my PowerPoint presentation.

15
00:00:43.780 --> 00:00:45.670
This is taking it one step further.

16
00:00:45.670 --> 00:00:48.770
This is actually taking content
from somewhere else and

17
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:52.240
linking it,
putting it into our presentation and

18
00:00:52.240 --> 00:00:57.760
creating that connection to
that data from wherever it is.

19
00:00:57.760 --> 00:01:01.028
For example,
let's say we have an Excel Chart, or

20
00:01:01.028 --> 00:01:05.514
we have information in Excel in a table,
or however it's formatted.

21
00:01:05.514 --> 00:01:09.747
And these are the weekly sales
numbers that I'm always going to have

22
00:01:09.747 --> 00:01:13.510
to be presenting to the sales
team at our weekly meeting.

23
00:01:13.510 --> 00:01:18.028
Why would I want to go ahead and recreate
that every single time in PowerPoint if

24
00:01:18.028 --> 00:01:19.816
I've already got it in Excel?

25
00:01:19.816 --> 00:01:23.514
If it changes in Excel,
I want it to change in PowerPoint so

26
00:01:23.514 --> 00:01:28.200
you can create that linked information and
have it ready to go at any time.

27
00:01:28.200 --> 00:01:31.950
So I think that is a really
handy way of being able to use

28
00:01:31.950 --> 00:01:36.350
office products across the board and
be able to say bring this into there and

29
00:01:36.350 --> 00:01:38.580
you can do this across multiple programs.

30
00:01:38.580 --> 00:01:40.680
So it doesn't just go one way but

31
00:01:40.680 --> 00:01:44.680
being able to have that content
linked is going to be important.

32
00:01:44.680 --> 00:01:46.680
And I have a PowerPoint
presentation ready to go,

33
00:01:46.680 --> 00:01:50.780
that's going to give us a couple
more tidbits of information before

34
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:53.450
we actually start adding some information,
adding that external content.

35
00:01:53.450 --> 00:01:56.440
So why don't we go ahead and
jump right into our link and

36
00:01:56.440 --> 00:01:57.900
embed PowerPoint presentation.

37
00:01:59.510 --> 00:02:01.590
And on slide two,

38
00:02:01.590 --> 00:02:04.160
it is going to cover some of
the information that I want to talk about.

39
00:02:04.160 --> 00:02:07.280
But before we get into slide two,
what is this?

40
00:02:07.280 --> 00:02:08.870
What's going on here?

41
00:02:08.870 --> 00:02:13.493
Well, I actually already put in some
linked content into this PowerPoint

42
00:02:13.493 --> 00:02:18.353
presentation to show you what it looks
like before we actually do it ourself.

43
00:02:18.353 --> 00:02:21.495
And this right here is giving me
a warn and says, hey guess what?

44
00:02:21.495 --> 00:02:23.365
You are link to other files.

45
00:02:23.365 --> 00:02:27.045
Are you sure that you want to be able to
retrieve all the information from that

46
00:02:27.045 --> 00:02:31.175
file and do you know where it
came from and are, is this safe?

47
00:02:31.175 --> 00:02:32.800
Are you sure you wanna do this?

48
00:02:32.800 --> 00:02:34.029
I know where I got this content.

49
00:02:34.029 --> 00:02:35.090
I know where it came from.

50
00:02:35.090 --> 00:02:37.880
It came from me, so I think we're okay.

51
00:02:37.880 --> 00:02:42.130
So we're gonna go ahead and update this
link and be able to say, yes go ahead and

52
00:02:42.130 --> 00:02:42.750
do that.

53
00:02:42.750 --> 00:02:44.030
>> It's a great point to make that.

54
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:47.746
You might download a presentation,
a demo or something from the internet or

55
00:02:47.746 --> 00:02:50.889
get something sent to you by
somebody you don't know that well.

56
00:02:50.889 --> 00:02:54.966
And all of a sudden you try to open it
up and it says it's reaching out and

57
00:02:54.966 --> 00:02:59.269
getting content from somewhere else,
do you really trust that, right?

58
00:02:59.269 --> 00:03:02.365
You've got to be careful because it
could do bad things to your machine or

59
00:03:02.365 --> 00:03:02.950
your data.

60
00:03:02.950 --> 00:03:05.110
>> Exactly.
You should always be careful and

61
00:03:05.110 --> 00:03:08.100
I'm always glad I'm doing these
episodes with you because

62
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:09.295
you know all about the security.

63
00:03:09.295 --> 00:03:10.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it was a great time

64
00:03:10.660 --> 00:03:14.384
filler because you see, it took a little
bit of time for that to actually to

65
00:03:14.384 --> 00:03:18.608
start up a little bit because it was going
out to find all of those links, all right?

66
00:03:18.608 --> 00:03:23.098
You, cuz when I made this file it was
like, you told me where that file was.

67
00:03:23.098 --> 00:03:26.727
So, I'm going to go out into your file
system, and go ahead find that file,

68
00:03:26.727 --> 00:03:29.340
get the information, update the content.

69
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:33.144
If you have multiple files that are linked
into this PowerPoint presentation,

70
00:03:33.144 --> 00:03:36.433
it might take a little bit for
it to kind of scan and find everything and

71
00:03:36.433 --> 00:03:40.034
say alright now I'm ready to go ahead and
display the information for you.

72
00:03:40.034 --> 00:03:41.392
So thank you for that time filler.

73

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike demonstrate how to package a PowerPoint presentation. They demonstrate what happens to a PowerPoint presentation with linked or embeded content when not packaged properly. Then they package a PowerPoint presentation properly, to include external content.
episodes.title: Link and Embed External Content Part 2

thank you for coming back and

00:11:57.322 --> 00:12:00.980
rounding out that information we've
learned a lot about linking and embedding.

221
00:12:00.980 --> 00:12:04.726
In that first episode now we learned how
to package it up and get it ready for

222
00:12:04.726 --> 00:12:07.024
transport if I need to
send it to somebody, or

223
00:12:07.024 --> 00:12:09.820
take it with me to give my
presentation out on the road.

224
00:12:09.820 --> 00:12:10.820
So we appreciate that.

225
00:12:10.820 --> 00:12:12.003
>> Thank you.
>> We hope everybody out

226
00:12:12.003 --> 00:12:13.520
there enjoyed watching this one.

227
00:12:13.520 --> 00:12:16.220
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Mike Rodrick

228
00:12:16.220 --> 00:12:17.070
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

229
00:12:17.070 --> 00:12:18.427
>> And we'll see you next time.

230
00:12:18.427 --> 00:12:25.000
[MUSIC]

231
00:12:25.000 --> 00:12:28.218
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike look at how to insert audio and video into a PowerPoint presentation. They demonstrate adding an audio clip, as well as adding a looping background audio track. Then they demonstrate adding video clips, both local and linking to an online video.
episodes.title: Audio and Video
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.290
Welcome to IT PRO.TV,

2
00:00:03.290 --> 00:00:08.226
I am your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:08.226 --> 00:00:12.023
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.023 --> 00:00:15.147
>> Hello, Welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPRO.TV,

5
00:00:15.147 --> 00:00:19.421
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our advanced PowerPoint 2016.

6
00:00:19.421 --> 00:00:23.880
Specifically in this episode, we're going
to be taking a look at ways we can insert

7
00:00:23.880 --> 00:00:27.410
audio and
video into our PowerPoint presentation.

8
00:00:27.410 --> 00:00:28.710
I know, it sounds really cool, right?

9
00:00:28.710 --> 00:00:31.740
I'm excited as well and here to show
us how to do it is Ms. Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:31.740 --> 00:00:32.720
Welcome back Vonne.

11
00:00:32.720 --> 00:00:33.220
>> Thanks.

12
00:00:33.220 --> 00:00:37.690
Yes, we're going to be putting in
the stars of the show, Fuego and Bishop,

13
00:00:37.690 --> 00:00:43.140
back into our presentation in an audio and
a visual format.

14
00:00:43.140 --> 00:00:47.210
Because what better way
to show how adorable Mr.

15
00:00:47.210 --> 00:00:51.885
Fuego Pants is, is to show a video of him
chasing a computer mouse on the screen.

16
00:00:51.885 --> 00:00:53.765
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes, that's exactly, cat and mouse

17
00:00:53.765 --> 00:00:54.890
>> That's my cat.

18
00:00:54.890 --> 00:00:56.340
>> I get it I get it.

19
00:00:56.340 --> 00:00:58.900
>> So yeah, so why would you want to?

20
00:00:58.900 --> 00:01:02.676
Because videos sometimes will show
great examples of what you're trying to

21
00:01:02.676 --> 00:01:03.451
demonstrate.

22
00:01:03.451 --> 00:01:07.500
Maybe you want to demonstrate
how to install a mailbox.

23
00:01:07.500 --> 00:01:11.240
We had our good friend Nate here in
the office installing a mailbox and

24
00:01:11.240 --> 00:01:16.150
I should clarify that this is a physical
mailbox not an Outlook mailbox.

25
00:01:16.150 --> 00:01:20.690
So he was out there and we made a joke
that we should make a video on how

26
00:01:20.690 --> 00:01:24.770
to install a mailbox and
I thought it was quite clever honestly.

27
00:01:24.770 --> 00:01:27.381
>> I do too. [LAUGH] >> [LAUGH] But
it's already installed, so

28
00:01:27.381 --> 00:01:28.996
we missed that opportunity.

29
00:01:28.996 --> 00:01:33.465
So we're going to be doing that, and how
are you going to be getting your audio and

30
00:01:33.465 --> 00:01:36.644
video files,
there's a whole bunch of different ways.

31
00:01:36.644 --> 00:01:41.489
But there is something to make sure
that you are familiar with is that

32
00:01:41.489 --> 00:01:46.334
different audio and video files
really make a difference because if

33
00:01:46.334 --> 00:01:50.780
you don't have the right codec
then something could be a lie.

34
00:01:50.780 --> 00:01:52.470
So, what is a codec?

35
00:01:52.470 --> 00:01:53.270
Mike, what is a codec?

36
00:01:53.270 --> 00:01:54.040
>> I don't know.

37
00:01:54.040 --> 00:01:54.810
I'm glad you're here to tell us.

38
00:01:54.810 --> 00:01:57.395
[LAUGH]
>> You know what it is.

39
00:01:57.395 --> 00:02:01.275
>> I'm gonna assume that it is what
it's gonna decode or code our video or

40
00:02:01.275 --> 00:02:02.345
audio stream, right?

41
00:02:02.345 --> 00:02:05.185
>> Yes, it is a program and
a device that is used for encoding and

42
00:02:05.185 --> 00:02:06.635
decoding a digital data stream.

43
00:02:06.635 --> 00:02:09.597
Yes, I wanted to read that to make
sure that I got that correct as well.

44
00:02:09.597 --> 00:02:10.097
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

45
00:02:10.097 --> 00:02:12.655
>> But we use it so frequently it's just,

46
00:02:12.655 --> 00:02:16.764
it's like the language almost
of being able to have the files,

47
00:02:16.764 --> 00:02:21.790
it speaks in a certain language and
making sure that we understand that.

48
00:02:21.790 --> 00:02:25.800
And so you gotta make sure that you have
that right codec or the right format for

49
00:02:25.800 --> 00:02:27.780
it to play in whatever
device that you have.

50
00:02:27.780 --> 00:02:31.920
>> Right cuz if somebody had put
a video of a certain file type in their

51
00:02:31.920 --> 00:02:33.940
PowerPoint, you try to play it but

52
00:02:33.940 --> 00:02:37.440
didn't have the codec that was used to
encode that video in the first place,

53
00:02:37.440 --> 00:02:39.550
your system wouldn't be able to decode it,
play the video and

54
00:02:39.550 --> 00:02:41.440
you're just gonna get an error
>> Exactly, yeah.

55
00:02:41.440 --> 00:02:46.080
And that actually happens,
an example would be like a I know my mom.

56
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:50.121
She has both a windows in a Mac
computer or maybe she's on Mac,

57
00:02:50.121 --> 00:02:53.513
she goes to a computer pretty quickly,
honestly.

58
00:02:53.513 --> 00:02:56.611
[LAUGH] But somebody has sent her
a video file and she wanted to watch and

59
00:02:56.611 --> 00:02:58.117
she's like, I can't watch it.

60
00:02:58.117 --> 00:02:59.459
It won't let me.

61
00:02:59.459 --> 00:03:01.930
I'm like, well, why not?

62
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:02.630
Just play it.

63
00:03:02.630 --> 00:03:07.731
She goes, yes, but it opens and
it says that I can't find the MOV file or

64
00:03:07.731 --> 00:03:13.405
a WMV, and I'm like, wait,
this is where you have a difference

65
00:03:13.405 --> 00:03:19.300
of it was creating or encoded or
saved as an MOV file,

66
00:03:19.300 --> 00:03:23.060
Then your Windows machine won't be
able to read it, or vice-versa.

67
00:03:23.060 --> 00:03:28.140
If it was created on a Windows machine
with that MWV, Windows Media Video?

68
00:03:28.140 --> 00:03:32.400
Yeah, and then she's trying to play it on
her Mac and it just wasn't understanding.

69
00:03:32.400 --> 00:03:33.810
It was like, I don't speak this language,

70
00:03:33.810 --> 00:03:38.880
and I don't have any program that will
allow me to understand what you're saying.

71
00:03:38.880 --> 00:03:44.940
The world of audio and
video files can have that issue sometimes.

72
00:03:44.940 --> 00:03:48.980
And so just make sure you
understand at least that there

73
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:52.890
are different file formats, and sometimes
you don't have the right thing to read it.

74
00:03:53.890 --> 00:03:58.850
But there are some free video encoders or
translators if you want to call

75
00:03:58.850 --> 00:04:03.630
them that you can download and
you can take an MOV file and

76
00:04:03.630 --> 00:04:09.400
change it into an MP4 file or an MP3 or
whatever file you want it to be.

77
00:04:09.400 --> 00:04:10.995
MOV is video, so it'd be MP4.

78
00:04:10.995 --> 00:04:13.746
So since I'm throwing out
all these letters and

79
00:04:13.746 --> 00:04:16.631
numbers right here,
I do have a list to go ahead and

80
00:04:16.631 --> 00:04:20.377
give you a little reference chart
in our file of audio and video.

81
00:04:20.377 --> 00:04:23.660
And it is coming directly
from the Microsoft website.

82
00:04:23.660 --> 00:04:26.790
So I did include the link that
you can be able to click on and

83
00:04:26.790 --> 00:04:30.010
be able to read up a little
bit more about this.

84
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:35.210
So here are some common audio file formats
such as the MP3, that's probably one that

85
00:04:35.210 --> 00:04:40.630
many of us are familiar with because
of our iPods and our MP3 players.

86
00:04:40.630 --> 00:04:45.780
It plays that type of file and
it's a very popular codec or

87
00:04:45.780 --> 00:04:49.420
translation of audio
files that people use.

88
00:04:49.420 --> 00:04:53.470
But there are other ones out there
that you might see or come across,

89
00:04:53.470 --> 00:04:58.240
like a wav, a wave file,
I've seen that quite frequently.

90
00:04:58.240 --> 00:05:03.340
Or you have the m4a, that's something
that you really see with Apple products.

91
00:05:03.340 --> 00:05:08.730
So if you have music from your Phone, it
will come down as that a lot of times so.

92
00:05:08.730 --> 00:05:13.276
And then there's some video file
formats here, you can see the MP4,

93
00:05:13.276 --> 00:05:15.069
another popular one M4V.

94
00:05:15.069 --> 00:05:17.190
And you also have the MOV.

95
00:05:17.190 --> 00:05:21.120
MOV is more of an Apple
base file format and

96
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:24.430
the WMV is going to be more of
a Windows media file as well.

97
00:05:24.430 --> 00:05:27.970
There is some flash there
in with the Swift files,

98
00:05:27.970 --> 00:05:31.910
the SWF files that you might still see.

99
00:05:31.910 --> 00:05:38.456
That file format and flash all together
is kind of reduced, we'll say.

100
00:05:38.456 --> 00:05:41.861
You don't see them as much with
the whole media flash war, but

101
00:05:41.861 --> 00:05:46.132
that is a whole other topic and it's
just a little older, I guess you'd say.

102
00:05:46.132 --> 00:05:46.942
>> We'll save that for another episode.

103
00:05:46.942 --> 00:05:48.458
>> Yeah, right [LAUGH] exactly.

104
00:05:48.458 --> 00:05:51.013
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay so as long as you know that we

105
00:05:51.013 --> 00:05:55.445
have some file formats to consider
when inserting into PowerPoint.

106
00:05:55.445 --> 00:05:58.725
The cool thing is, once you start
getting in the, if you have a file and

107
00:05:58.725 --> 00:06:02.875
you try to put it into PowerPoint, if it
has a problem, it will give you a warning.

108
00:06:02.875 --> 00:06:06.905
It will say like, I don't understand this,
I'm not reading it properly.

109
00:06:06.905 --> 00:06:12.035
So, it'll tell you if something is
gone all right within PowerPoint.

110
00:06:13.310 --> 00:06:15.280

00:06:15.280 --> 00:06:17.240
You're gonna have to get
them from somewhere and

I actually do have some files

Just wanna give you a quick

00:06:26.690 --> 00:06:32.510
I have some M4A files and
I have some M4V files.

116
00:06:32.510 --> 00:06:34.340
These did come of of my iPhone.

00:06:34.340 --> 00:06:40.515
I use the Voice Memo app and I [LAUGH]

>> They were very confused like why

00:06:42.720 --> 00:06:44.715

>> [LAUGH]

00:06:48.986 --> 00:06:53.073

123
00:06:57.002 --> 00:07:00.080
>> [LAUGH] [SOUND]
>> Yes,

124

>> Yeah, that's not happy.

126

>> Let me down.

127
00:07:02.332 --> 00:07:04.170
>> [LAUGH] I think that.

So I have some sound

00:07:07.860 --> 00:07:12.981

00:07:12.981 --> 00:07:19.385

00:07:25.067 --> 00:07:27.520

I also have some video files

[LAUGH] So I have an actual file,

00:08:00.680 --> 00:08:03.235

00:08:03.235 --> 00:08:05.290
Yes, so we're gonna show you and

144
00:08:05.290 --> 00:08:06.581
>> Yeah.
>> Remember it wasn't.

00:08:06.581 --> 00:08:08.450

you'll see, cliffhanger
>> [LAUGH] So, I have some audio and

00:08:19.450 --> 00:08:22.410
Audio clips, if you're
downloading them from the web and

Pictures, and whatever the case maybe,

00:08:34.120 --> 00:08:36.430
Here is the file from my device.

155
00:08:36.430 --> 00:08:37.200

00:08:37.200 --> 00:08:37.930

00:08:37.930 --> 00:08:41.050

We're gonna come over to our Media group

161

Now, I'm gonna go out and

00:08:58.410 --> 00:09:04.080

164
00:09:04.080 --> 00:09:06.400
I could go ahead and make it bigger.

165
00:09:06.400 --> 00:09:11.240
This is just my visual
representation of the sound file.

166
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:17.300
>> That I will be able to play on click,
and that is the default playback setting,

167
00:09:17.300 --> 00:09:19.810
and you will see that there

168
00:09:19.810 --> 00:09:23.950

169

What if I don't like the speaker icon?

170
00:09:27.165 --> 00:09:33.610
It indicates sound, but I wanted to like

171
00:09:33.610 --> 00:09:37.940
You can change, what this icon looks like,
because you can see in the audio

tools contextual tabs,
we have a format and we have a playback.

173
00:09:42.310 --> 00:09:46.910
So, the format is going to
format the visual picture,

174
00:09:46.910 --> 00:09:49.560
in this case the speaker picture.

175
00:09:49.560 --> 00:09:54.580
And I could make borders and I could

176
00:09:54.580 --> 00:09:58.830
just like I would with any type of image,
but I want to change the picture,

177
00:10:00.250 --> 00:10:02.750
there is this weird thing that's
happening on my computer.

178
00:10:03.790 --> 00:10:05.535
I honestly, can't tell you why.

179
00:10:05.535 --> 00:10:08.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> I should have a little icon right here,

180
00:10:08.950 --> 00:10:11.520
that says change picture.

181
00:10:11.520 --> 00:10:12.200
It's not there.

182
00:10:13.350 --> 00:10:15.000
I really don't know why.

183
00:10:16.360 --> 00:10:21.065
Let me switch over to Joey's computer,
I was Justin, now I'm Joey.

184
00:10:21.065 --> 00:10:26.040
Cuz, I did the exact same file, or
well the same audio file inserted

185
00:10:26.040 --> 00:10:31.620
into this PowerPoint presentation
on his format tab right there.

186
00:10:31.620 --> 00:10:32.340
Let's change picture.

187
00:10:33.970 --> 00:10:36.130
So, if for some reason,
you're like me, and

188
00:10:36.130 --> 00:10:39.600
you don't know why that, like picture,
change picture is not available.

189
00:10:39.600 --> 00:10:42.260
I don't really know either.

190
00:10:42.260 --> 00:10:44.865
But, it's okay, because we can always.

191
00:10:44.865 --> 00:10:47.340
What's wrong virtual machine, here we go.

192
00:10:47.340 --> 00:10:48.960
We can always change it.

193
00:10:48.960 --> 00:10:52.780
Remember back if you'd watched the first
series of the PowerPoint 2016.

194
00:10:52.780 --> 00:10:57.640
You can always add commands that you
don't see, or you don't commonly use.

195
00:10:57.640 --> 00:10:59.790
On the quick access tool bar and

196
00:10:59.790 --> 00:11:03.630
that is actually what I did right here
the change picture cuz, it does exist.

197
00:11:03.630 --> 00:11:05.520
It is part of the program.

198
00:11:05.520 --> 00:11:07.400
It just not displaying for
me for some reason.

199
00:11:07.400 --> 00:11:11.210
But, just to remind you really quickly,
you can always go to the more commands and

200
00:11:11.210 --> 00:11:14.500
then you can find the command
that you're looking for.

201
00:11:14.500 --> 00:11:17.920
I know that it is on the audio tools.

202
00:11:17.920 --> 00:11:21.670
Format tab and
then I found the change picture.

203
00:11:21.670 --> 00:11:25.219
And then I added it to
my quick access toolbar.

204
00:11:25.219 --> 00:11:25.928
>> Perfect.

205
00:11:25.928 --> 00:11:29.420
>> So, we're going to click
on that to change picture.

206
00:11:29.420 --> 00:11:33.316
And then I can go out and you can either
find a file on your computer cuz,

207
00:11:33.316 --> 00:11:36.953
maybe I created, maybe just a little
picture of Bishop's face or

208
00:11:36.953 --> 00:11:40.083
it says meow well,
I don't have any of that ready to go.

209
00:11:40.083 --> 00:11:43.817

before you start your screen recording,

434
00:24:29.550 --> 00:24:33.130
and then I can go ahead and set the area

00:24:33.130 --> 00:24:37.940
I don't want to record my entire screen,
I only want to designate this part.

436
00:24:37.940 --> 00:24:40.440
So, you ahead and
set what you want it to be.

437
00:24:40.440 --> 00:24:44.810
Whether it is your full screen or not and
then you go ahead and click record,

438
00:24:44.810 --> 00:24:46.460
and it will count you down.

439
00:24:46.460 --> 00:24:51.090
So, you get ready, to say what I wanna

you come over here to your quick
access and you click desktop and

442

443

444

But if you did not want to record

just turn that option off.

448
00:25:17.950 --> 00:25:21.370
And now, I have my screen recording,
it is not going to be

in high definition because it is
it's going directly into Powerpoint.

450
00:25:25.870 --> 00:25:29.454
But for a demonstration purposes,
it is going to look pretty decent.

451
00:25:29.454 --> 00:25:34.951
But I know that I went ahead-
>> How you get to your desktop is-

452
00:25:34.951 --> 00:25:35.550
>> I scared myself.

453
00:25:35.550 --> 00:25:37.354
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

454

I know that right about here is where

455
00:25:43.340 --> 00:25:47.630
This is where you can go to your playback,
you can trim that out and

456
00:25:47.630 --> 00:25:49.020

457
00:25:49.020 --> 00:25:54.635
I want it to stop about, that would

And that's the part where I don't want

460
00:25:59.875 --> 00:26:05.265
And then you can go ahead and trim your

461
00:26:05.265 --> 00:26:08.715
And so,
that's how you can get a screen recording

462
00:26:08.715 --> 00:26:10.495

463
00:26:10.495 --> 00:26:11.885
>> All right, fantastic, Vonne.

464
00:26:11.885 --> 00:26:14.845
Great look there at how we can
insert audio, insert video.

Whether we get it from the web or

466

Or whether we record it live on our

467

Fantastic stuff, and I know you got

out of time for this one.

469

So we'll cut it off now,

00:26:29.590 --> 00:26:31.730
So, I hope everybody out there

00:26:31.730 --> 00:26:34.670
Sounding off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

474
00:26:37.088 --> 00:26:42.935
[MUSIC]

475
00:26:42.935 --> 00:26:46.518
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike continue their look at inserting audio and video into a PowerPoint presentation. They demonstrate adding video clips, both local and linking to an online video. They also show how to prepare a slideshow for distribution and add narration to a presentation.
episodes.title: Audio and Video Part 2
episodes.transcript:

Cuz I have other examples in there

If you look at the file size,

kb thats 74 megs right there or

Yes, 1024,
1024 bytes in a megabyte, right?

So basically, this is a big file.

It's a pretty decent sized file

Nowadays if you have a newer computer and

this shouldn't be any of,

it's really up to you

176
00:10:22.390 --> 00:10:26.440
I would suggest keeping it embedded
because then you don't have

to remember but

>> I was trying to think
