episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike discuss collaboration methods in PowerPoint 2016. They look at adding comments and highlighting with the Inking feature. They also demonstrate using the compare option to find changes that were not commented.
episodes.title: Comment and Compare
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:02.340
Welcome ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:02.340 --> 00:00:12.068
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.068 --> 00:00:15.343
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV,

4
00:00:15.343 --> 00:00:16.900
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:16.900 --> 00:00:19.700
And today,
were doing our advance PowerPoint 2016.

6
00:00:19.700 --> 00:00:24.321
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at how we can comment and

7
00:00:24.321 --> 00:00:27.350
compare, basically
collaborate with other users.

8
00:00:27.350 --> 00:00:30.660
We're typically not working in an isolated
little island, we've got coworkers.

9
00:00:30.660 --> 00:00:34.100
And we want to create presentations with,
share presentations with.

10
00:00:34.100 --> 00:00:36.610
So, here to help us with this is Ms.
Vonne Smith.

11
00:00:36.610 --> 00:00:37.490
Welcome back, Vonne.

12
00:00:37.490 --> 00:00:40.860
>> Thank you, yeah, we're going to be
working with PowerPoint presentations with

13
00:00:40.860 --> 00:00:43.730
not just yourself, with somebody else.

14
00:00:43.730 --> 00:00:47.300
So let's say that I have created
a Powerpoint presentation and

15
00:00:47.300 --> 00:00:48.900
I need your help.

16
00:00:48.900 --> 00:00:51.480
I need you to edit the presentation.

17
00:00:51.480 --> 00:00:56.840
Maybe add some information and
so what I could do is I can put

18
00:00:56.840 --> 00:01:00.590
comments in my PowerPoint presentation for
you to follow.

19
00:01:00.590 --> 00:01:03.214
And it's gonna be writing
notes in the margin, right?

20
00:01:03.214 --> 00:01:05.570
So I have a piece of paper I'm
gonna write little notes in.

21
00:01:05.570 --> 00:01:08.720
And kind of just something to remind me,
or

22
00:01:08.720 --> 00:01:11.150
if I'm sending it to you to
direct you at where you're going.

23
00:01:11.150 --> 00:01:14.460
So, you don't always have
to be working with somebody

24
00:01:14.460 --> 00:01:17.600
else to put comments into
your PowerPoint presentation.

25
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:19.060
It could be for you.

26
00:01:19.060 --> 00:01:20.610
I need to make notes to
myself all the time.

27
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.004
I mean [LAUGH] I have to write it down,
this is what I'm going to do.

28
00:01:23.004 --> 00:01:24.659
This is what I have to
pick up from home and

29
00:01:24.659 --> 00:01:26.540
just to remind myself of what I'm doing.

30
00:01:26.540 --> 00:01:29.070
>> So you could have a little not
there that says reminder to self,

31
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:31.540
insert sound clip here.

32
00:01:31.540 --> 00:01:34.990
Or hey, Joey, what do you think of
this picture, does it work for us?

33
00:01:34.990 --> 00:01:35.780
>> Exactly, yeah.

34
00:01:35.780 --> 00:01:40.850
So the audience of who it's intended for
is really up to you.

35
00:01:40.850 --> 00:01:43.490
It could be intended for you or for

36
00:01:43.490 --> 00:01:45.910
somebody else that you're
sending this along to.

37
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:47.550
So let's go ahead and

38
00:01:47.550 --> 00:01:52.380
get into the file that we are going
to be adding comments, too.

39
00:01:52.380 --> 00:01:54.530
And I am using images for review.

40
00:01:56.258 --> 00:01:57.412
And here we go.

41
00:01:57.412 --> 00:02:01.396
So I've got my presentation,
and I need to send it to Mike,

42
00:02:01.396 --> 00:02:05.160
you're gonna turn into Joey,
by the way, okay [LAUGH].

43
00:02:05.160 --> 00:02:09.917
And I'm gonna actually be logging in
as Joey and showing you kind of both,

44
00:02:09.917 --> 00:02:13.410
where we have multiple people
in this episode [LAUGH].

45
00:02:13.410 --> 00:02:16.087
>> All my personalities will be very
happy with this episode [LAUGH].

46
00:02:16.087 --> 00:02:17.995
>> [LAUGH] So will mine, so.

47
00:02:17.995 --> 00:02:21.040
[LAUGH] So I am Justin right now.

48
00:02:21.040 --> 00:02:23.980
Hi, and so
this is my PowerPoint presentation,

49
00:02:23.980 --> 00:02:27.120
I want to send this to Mike but
I wanna give him comments.

50
00:02:27.120 --> 00:02:29.348
Where do I go to insert a comment?

51
00:02:29.348 --> 00:02:31.750
You can go to Insert,
you can go to Comment or

52
00:02:31.750 --> 00:02:35.280
you can also click this little button
right over here in the upper right-hand

53
00:02:35.280 --> 00:02:38.440
corner in your ribbon that will go
ahead and open up the comments as well.

54
00:02:38.440 --> 00:02:40.740
Either one is gonna get
you to the same place.

55
00:02:40.740 --> 00:02:42.730
It's almost like taking sticky notes and

56
00:02:42.730 --> 00:02:47.150
putting a sticky note on the slide to
indicate yep, this is what I want to say.

57
00:02:47.150 --> 00:02:51.064
So I'm gonna go ahead and
add a new comment and

58
00:02:51.064 --> 00:02:55.708
I'm going to say please edit and
pick a design theme.

59
00:02:55.708 --> 00:03:00.784
And that indicates right here,
this little, almost like this Sticky note,

60
00:03:00.784 --> 00:03:05.487
that little comment bubble,
that there is a comment in this document.

61
00:03:05.487 --> 00:03:07.058
>> Vonne, and it looks like
it's picking up your name and

62
00:03:07.058 --> 00:03:08.570
everything from maybe who
you already logged in as?

63
00:03:08.570 --> 00:03:09.420
>> Yeah, it is the account.

64
00:03:09.420 --> 00:03:11.170
>> Okay.
>> This is my Office 365 account.

65
00:03:11.170 --> 00:03:11.810
>> Very nice.

66
00:03:11.810 --> 00:03:14.435
>> So this is why it knows
that I am Justin Timberlake.

67
00:03:14.435 --> 00:03:16.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

68
00:03:16.100 --> 00:03:17.830
I'm gonna add a comment here.

69
00:03:17.830 --> 00:03:21.090
Why don't I go ahead and add comments to,
there's already a comment.

70
00:03:21.090 --> 00:03:21.768
I forgot about this.

71
00:03:21.768 --> 00:03:23.510
[LAUGH] So I already put this in,

72
00:03:23.510 --> 00:03:27.650
I must have forgot to delete it before
I save the file for you guys to see.

73
00:03:27.650 --> 00:03:31.470
But that is what I wanted to
add was to add another comment.

74
00:03:31.470 --> 00:03:36.640
While I'm here, if I didn't like that,
I don't want that to comment cuz maybe

75
00:03:36.640 --> 00:03:40.190
I left it there and
forgot [LAUGH] like I did and said.

76
00:03:40.190 --> 00:03:44.740
Nope, I changed my mind, you can just
delete it from your presentation,

77
00:03:44.740 --> 00:03:46.350
just as you would any object.

78
00:03:46.350 --> 00:03:49.290
And then it just shows there
are no comments in this slide.

79
00:03:49.290 --> 00:03:53.390
So you can take away a comment
if you wanted to, but

80
00:03:53.390 --> 00:03:56.690
I'm gonna go ahead and add that in,
and I'm going to add the same thing.

81
00:03:56.690 --> 00:04:02.890
Please pick an image, and you could
comment to the [INAUDIBLE] come home.

82
00:04:02.890 --> 00:04:06.610
And anything that you need for any slide,
you can put multiple comments in.

83
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:09.470
It doesn't mean that you can
only have one comment per slide.

84
00:04:09.470 --> 00:04:12.560
You can put in 15 comments and
you can attach it to different things.

85
00:04:12.560 --> 00:04:15.010
Because maybe you wanted to put
a comment next to a picture,

86
00:04:15.010 --> 00:04:17.100
or put a comment next to some text.

87
00:04:17.100 --> 00:04:22.446
And so you can move these around to
the places that you want to kind

88
00:04:22.446 --> 00:04:27.495
of notify yourself as to why your
commenting on this object or

89
00:04:27.495 --> 00:04:31.264
this thing in the PowerPoint presentation.

90
00:04:31.264 --> 00:04:35.341
There is something else that
you can do with marking up or

91
00:04:35.341 --> 00:04:37.710
commenting on your slides.

92
00:04:37.710 --> 00:04:39.130
And that's something known as inking,

93
00:04:39.130 --> 00:04:41.990
it's sort of almost like
taking your highlighters.

94
00:04:41.990 --> 00:04:46.190
And actually highlighting or circling,
it's like drawing, just as if I was

95
00:04:46.190 --> 00:04:51.870
an editor for a magazine or
I was editing somebody's term paper.

96
00:04:51.870 --> 00:04:53.890
>> Like Old English teacher, yeah.

97
00:04:53.890 --> 00:04:55.360
>> All about the red pen.

98
00:04:55.360 --> 00:04:56.245
>> Yeah.

99
00:04:56.245 --> 00:04:57.378
I got a few frowny faces.

100
00:04:57.378 --> 00:05:02.593
>> [LAUGH] I can't imagine
you get a frowny face.

101
00:05:02.593 --> 00:05:03.905
>> [LAUGH]
>> You probably had a lot.

102
00:05:03.905 --> 00:05:05.947
>> [LAUGH]
>> And they started using green pen,

103
00:05:05.947 --> 00:05:08.426
cuz it's got a different
connotation than using the red pen.

104
00:05:08.426 --> 00:05:08.950
>> Yeah.

105
00:05:08.950 --> 00:05:11.885
>> Cuz a red indicates bad and
a green is good.

106
00:05:11.885 --> 00:05:14.089
>> Yeah, constructive criticism.

107
00:05:14.089 --> 00:05:15.163
>> Exactly, yes.

108
00:05:15.163 --> 00:05:19.976
[LAUGH] So you can go over to the Review
tab and you can go to the start inking.

109
00:05:19.976 --> 00:05:23.904
And it's just like taking out
a set of highlighters or pens, and

110
00:05:23.904 --> 00:05:27.560
you can start marking up your
document however you wanted.

111
00:05:27.560 --> 00:05:33.258
For example,
if I wanted to maybe highlight here and

112
00:05:33.258 --> 00:05:37.021
I wanted to make a comment on that.

113
00:05:37.021 --> 00:05:38.447
Wait, let me back up.

114
00:05:38.447 --> 00:05:40.317
You can just go ahead and
mark anything but

115
00:05:40.317 --> 00:05:44.123
you're not going to maybe understand what
this is later, why did I highlight that?

116
00:05:44.123 --> 00:05:47.592
Now if it's me,
I might understand why I did, but

117
00:05:47.592 --> 00:05:51.650
you could always then ink things up and
then add a comment.

118
00:05:51.650 --> 00:05:54.990
They are two separate things though, so
I wanna make sure that you get that.

119
00:05:54.990 --> 00:05:58.440
That I can annotate, ink things up,

120
00:05:58.440 --> 00:06:02.570
come back over to my review,
and you can add a new comment.

121
00:06:02.570 --> 00:06:04.600
That's the third way that
you can get into it, sorry.

122
00:06:04.600 --> 00:06:07.850
I said insert and a little button,
there is a Review tab as well.

123
00:06:07.850 --> 00:06:12.260
So I could say new comments and
I can move this over and then since maybe,

124
00:06:12.260 --> 00:06:17.090
since I'm collaborating with Mike/Joey,
I could come over here and

125
00:06:17.090 --> 00:06:19.960
say, please explain.

126
00:06:21.400 --> 00:06:24.790
Or something to the effect
of why did I highlight that?

127
00:06:24.790 --> 00:06:27.240
So you can use them in conjunction,
and so that way

128
00:06:27.240 --> 00:06:31.380
you can really start collaborating
with each other as to what you want.

129
00:06:31.380 --> 00:06:36.964
Cuz maybe I'm editing Mike's presentation,

130
00:06:36.964 --> 00:06:42.127
maybe he sent it to me and
I wanted to just give

131
00:06:42.127 --> 00:06:49.397
a better representation of what
I'm trying to tell him to do.

132
00:06:49.397 --> 00:06:53.923
And I could make it red [LAUGH] and
bring it back to middle school, yeah,

133
00:06:53.923 --> 00:06:56.697
let's not do any flashbacks, all right.

134
00:06:56.697 --> 00:06:58.360
So that's how you can start
commenting your documents, so

135
00:06:58.360 --> 00:06:59.231
let's go ahead and save this.

136
00:06:59.231 --> 00:07:01.080
I'm going to say image, images for
review, and I will say Joey.

137
00:07:02.900 --> 00:07:05.630
And I will go up one level to put it
on my desktop, just so it's easier for

138
00:07:05.630 --> 00:07:08.270
me to find and I will go ahead and save.

139
00:07:08.270 --> 00:07:11.530
So I've went ahead and did all
the commenting, so now I would send this

140
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:17.890
presentation to Mike/Joey and
have him do all the edits that I'm asking.

141
00:07:17.890 --> 00:07:19.510
Now how would I send to to him?

142
00:07:19.510 --> 00:07:21.180
Easiest way really, just email.

143
00:07:21.180 --> 00:07:24.250
Or if we're on a shared drive,
I could tell him to go into that

144
00:07:24.250 --> 00:07:26.730
particular location and
then edit the document.

145
00:07:26.730 --> 00:07:32.420
So getting that physical file
to whoever you wanted to be,

146
00:07:32.420 --> 00:07:37.940
we're just going along the lines of
emailing or sending or that sort of way.

147
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:41.780
There is a whole service with the cloud
and how you can collaborate in the Cloud.

148
00:07:41.780 --> 00:07:44.805
But we're gonna save that for
another episode,

149
00:07:44.805 --> 00:07:48.882
in this one we're kinda do in
a more manual way of collaborating.

150
00:07:48.882 --> 00:07:49.550
>> Old school collaboration, yeah.

151
00:07:49.550 --> 00:07:50.710
>> Old school, yeah,
we'll call it old school.

152
00:07:50.710 --> 00:07:57.000
[LAUGH] So I am logged in right now
in this machine as Justin Timberlake.

153
00:07:57.000 --> 00:08:02.060
I have another computer, thanks to
the power of technology [LAUGH] and

154
00:08:02.060 --> 00:08:04.070
virtual machines that this is Joey.

155
00:08:04.070 --> 00:08:08.660
So let's pretend that my name is Joey
now and I'm going to get this file.

156
00:08:08.660 --> 00:08:10.014
Except the one thing that I've forgot.

157
00:08:10.014 --> 00:08:11.958
I needed to get the file over to Joey.

158
00:08:11.958 --> 00:08:19.170
Well, I have a shared folder across
all of my virtual machines and so

159
00:08:19.170 --> 00:08:25.110
I'm going to go ahead and put that folder,
that file into this folder right here.

160
00:08:25.110 --> 00:08:29.912
So that way, Joey will be able
to access it on his machine.

161
00:08:31.020 --> 00:08:31.630
>> Very good.

162
00:08:31.630 --> 00:08:34.044
>> Yeah, so shared drives-
>> So if you're using a shared drive

163
00:08:34.044 --> 00:08:34.646
at work.

164
00:08:34.646 --> 00:08:35.150
>> Mm-hm, yeah.

165
00:08:35.150 --> 00:08:37.752
I'm just, oops, that's my Mac.

166
00:08:37.752 --> 00:08:39.594
Let's go the other way [LAUGH].

167
00:08:39.594 --> 00:08:41.710
Here is my Joey Windows machine.

168
00:08:41.710 --> 00:08:45.083
And it's in the outback, like the Joeys.

169
00:08:45.083 --> 00:08:45.982
>> Clever.

170
00:08:45.982 --> 00:08:48.730
>> I know [LAUGH], thank you.

171
00:08:48.730 --> 00:08:51.450
So, I'm going to pretend
that I am Joey now.

172
00:08:52.680 --> 00:08:56.780
And I'm going to open
up my file as soon as

173
00:08:56.780 --> 00:09:01.440
my shared drives go ahead and
recognize each other.

174
00:09:01.440 --> 00:09:03.340
So image review for Joey.

175
00:09:03.340 --> 00:09:08.920
So here I am, I am Joey,
I am going to do what Justin has told me,

176
00:09:08.920 --> 00:09:11.970
and I am going to edit this document.

177
00:09:11.970 --> 00:09:15.134
I can see right here, yep,
that's what it's saying, please edit and

178
00:09:15.134 --> 00:09:15.838
pick a design.

179
00:09:15.838 --> 00:09:21.010
I can reply to that comment right there,
I could say, sure,

180
00:09:21.010 --> 00:09:27.512
if I could type that, sure, here you go,
and I could go through all of that.

181
00:09:27.512 --> 00:09:30.149
And then if you think about it,
we're going back and forth.

182
00:09:31.490 --> 00:09:35.090
Joey is going to send it back to Justin,
Justin can then comment on Joeys and

183
00:09:35.090 --> 00:09:36.010
we can go back and forth.

184
00:09:36.010 --> 00:09:39.128
And we can have a whole dialogue
with each other in the comments,

185
00:09:39.128 --> 00:09:43.174
which is pretty handy if you're talking
about working with some multiple people,

186
00:09:43.174 --> 00:09:45.570
or at least collaborating
with another person.

187
00:09:45.570 --> 00:09:50.710
So lets choose a design theme and
let's add an image.

188
00:09:50.710 --> 00:09:53.206
We'll go to online picture.

189
00:09:53.206 --> 00:09:57.310
And we are not going to type in cats.

190
00:09:57.310 --> 00:09:59.290
>> No.
>> I know, crazy,

191
00:09:59.290 --> 00:10:02.205
we're gonna type in a bunny.

192
00:10:02.205 --> 00:10:03.755
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so

193
00:10:03.755 --> 00:10:06.045
we're going out to find
our Internet search.

194
00:10:06.045 --> 00:10:11.730
Okay, lots of pictures
of adorable bunnies,

195
00:10:11.730 --> 00:10:15.450
I think we'll take that first one,
he looks like he's taking a little nap,

196
00:10:15.450 --> 00:10:18.160
that would be nice to
have right now [LAUGH].

197
00:10:18.160 --> 00:10:22.120
So we'll go ahead and insert our picture,
it does bring up our design ideas but

198
00:10:22.120 --> 00:10:24.720
I'm gonna go ahead and
just close that out.

199
00:10:24.720 --> 00:10:28.190
And I'm going to reply as Joey
to Justin and say, bunnies!

200
00:10:28.190 --> 00:10:31.622
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's got to have bunnies.

201
00:10:31.622 --> 00:10:36.970
And maybe down here, I can delete this
out, and I'm not making a comment

202
00:10:36.970 --> 00:10:41.986
specifically for demonstration purposes,
coming up in a second.

203
00:10:41.986 --> 00:10:46.308
And I'm also going to delete this slide.

204
00:10:46.308 --> 00:10:50.991
Because I'm as Joey, thinking that
you don't need that much text on

205
00:10:50.991 --> 00:10:55.850
that slide in slide four and you didn't
need a blink blue slide the end.

206
00:10:55.850 --> 00:11:00.029
So I deleted that, and
maybe I'll comment here and

207
00:11:00.029 --> 00:11:04.013
delete this text as well and
add something else,

208
00:11:04.013 --> 00:11:09.180
I'm just gonna say add text just for
demonstration purposes.

209
00:11:09.180 --> 00:11:12.600
So I did think but notice I didn't
indicate that I did anything.

210
00:11:12.600 --> 00:11:17.350
I did not leave a comment that said,
I deleted this slide, I changed this, so

211
00:11:17.350 --> 00:11:18.740
on and so forth.

212
00:11:18.740 --> 00:11:21.600
So, keep that in mind.

213
00:11:21.600 --> 00:11:23.450
I'm going to save
the changes to this file.

214
00:11:25.880 --> 00:11:30.170
And I will then switch
back over to Justin, and

215
00:11:30.170 --> 00:11:33.410
take on the role of Justin again.

216
00:11:33.410 --> 00:11:34.805
So, my other personality now.

217
00:11:34.805 --> 00:11:38.830
[LAUGH] So
Joey is done editing the document.

218
00:11:38.830 --> 00:11:43.890
I'm now Justin again and I am now going
to get all the changes from Joey.

219
00:11:44.950 --> 00:11:48.082
I'm going to go into my virtual machine.

220
00:11:48.082 --> 00:11:49.040
Images for Joey.

221
00:11:49.040 --> 00:11:53.280
It's going to load up in just a second.

222
00:11:53.280 --> 00:11:58.010
It's taking a little bit longer since
I'm connecting to my share drive.

223
00:11:59.240 --> 00:12:01.100
And I did make comments.

224
00:12:01.100 --> 00:12:06.880
So if I had go to the comments, I can see
that yes, Joey replied to me, here you go.

225
00:12:06.880 --> 00:12:10.570
I can see that he's comment here
is that he commented bunnies and

226
00:12:10.570 --> 00:12:15.640
if he had made any other comments, I would
be able to see all of the things that

227
00:12:15.640 --> 00:12:18.590
he answered in the comments that I gave.

228
00:12:18.590 --> 00:12:23.900
But I don't know that
he edited slide four.

229
00:12:23.900 --> 00:12:26.900
I know, but
let's just say there's 40 slides and

230
00:12:26.900 --> 00:12:32.100
I can't really see really quickly
that he added text on slide three.

231
00:12:33.300 --> 00:12:37.510
I'm kind of in a little bit of a conundrum
here, I don't know what he did.

232
00:12:37.510 --> 00:12:40.896
Well, there's this unique
feature called compare.

233
00:12:40.896 --> 00:12:44.410
And so what do you think we're
gonna do when we compare?

234
00:12:44.410 --> 00:12:46.151
>> Compare two things?
>> Exactly, [LAUGH].

235
00:12:46.151 --> 00:12:47.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> So that's

236
00:12:47.070 --> 00:12:48.690
exactly what we're going to do.

237
00:12:48.690 --> 00:12:52.480
The key here is that you
would want to compare

238
00:12:52.480 --> 00:12:56.070
two files that were somewhat the same.

239
00:12:56.070 --> 00:12:59.740
I mean if I compared my images for
review and learn PowerPoint,

240
00:12:59.740 --> 00:13:01.360
there's gonna be a huge
difference right there.

241
00:13:01.360 --> 00:13:06.572
So, you always wanna kind of have versions
of the same PowerPoint presentation,

242
00:13:06.572 --> 00:13:09.755
otherwise everything's
going to be different.

243
00:13:09.755 --> 00:13:14.264
So I'm going to open up my
original file that I had, and

244
00:13:14.264 --> 00:13:20.160
I'm going to put this on my desktop,
I already had one, that's okay.

245
00:13:20.160 --> 00:13:25.080
We'll replace it, that's fine, it's just
a little easier to pull from my hard drive

246
00:13:25.080 --> 00:13:28.348
or this computer rather than the shared
drive, it might take a little bit longer.

247
00:13:28.348 --> 00:13:32.710
So I'm gonna open up the images for
review, the one that I had,

248
00:13:32.710 --> 00:13:37.108
I just realized that I replaced that,
that's okay, we'll be all right.

249
00:13:37.108 --> 00:13:39.585
[LAUGH] I just realized I
saved it on my desktop.

250
00:13:39.585 --> 00:13:40.160
>> Uh-huh.

251
00:13:40.160 --> 00:13:41.900
>> It's okay, we're-
>> It's in your recycle bin.

252
00:13:41.900 --> 00:13:44.250
>> It is, well, and also,
I mean it came from this original file.

253
00:13:44.250 --> 00:13:44.890
>> That's true.
>> To begin with.

254
00:13:44.890 --> 00:13:46.260
So I think we'll be fine.

255
00:13:46.260 --> 00:13:51.290
We're gonna go over to our review and
we're gonna go over to compare.

256
00:13:51.290 --> 00:13:56.210
And now I'm going to open up that
file that Joey had made for me.

257
00:13:56.210 --> 00:13:59.370
That I put on my desktop, that I
overrode the changes from last time,

258
00:13:59.370 --> 00:14:00.170
but that's okay.

259
00:14:00.170 --> 00:14:02.920
So now you can see that it is telling me

260
00:14:02.920 --> 00:14:08.660
all the differences between my file and
the other file.

261
00:14:08.660 --> 00:14:12.768
On the Revisions pane,
it shows me the changes on each slide.

262
00:14:12.768 --> 00:14:14.752
And you can see there's these little,

263
00:14:14.752 --> 00:14:17.990
almost like little post-it
notes on each one of these.

264
00:14:17.990 --> 00:14:18.680
And I can click on them.

265
00:14:18.680 --> 00:14:21.429
And you see right here
on the slide properties,

266
00:14:21.429 --> 00:14:24.110
it starts to put in these
little check boxes and

267
00:14:24.110 --> 00:14:28.868
little boxes around all of the different
places that something has been changed.

268
00:14:28.868 --> 00:14:32.589
And you see in parenthesis
it says Joey Fatone,

269
00:14:32.589 --> 00:14:37.704
because it's showing who did what
based on the file properties or

270
00:14:37.704 --> 00:14:40.970
the user input that Joey saved this file.

271
00:14:40.970 --> 00:14:42.780
This is a file from Joey.

272
00:14:42.780 --> 00:14:45.870
And Justin,
who's the one who'd made the comments,

273
00:14:45.870 --> 00:14:48.610
that's gonna put in the parenthesis
of what, who did what.

274
00:14:49.840 --> 00:14:53.194
And if I check the box,
I could see there's a slide layout,

275
00:14:53.194 --> 00:14:55.509
then he went ahead and
added a design theme.

276
00:14:55.509 --> 00:15:00.075
If I go over to slide two,
there's some other little boxes here.

277
00:15:00.075 --> 00:15:03.865
If I click on here, Joey inserted
a picture I can check that on and

278
00:15:03.865 --> 00:15:04.675
say, well, there you go.

279
00:15:04.675 --> 00:15:10.747
So you can start comparing and contrasting
really what has been done by who and

280
00:15:10.747 --> 00:15:14.727
you can say yes, I want this,
or no, I do not want this.

281
00:15:14.727 --> 00:15:16.507
By checking them on or off or

282
00:15:16.507 --> 00:15:19.597
even better what if I checked this
one on to see cuz I didn't see

283
00:15:19.597 --> 00:15:24.473
what the picture was until I check
the box off, but maybe I don't like that.

284
00:15:24.473 --> 00:15:26.133
I do not like that picture of that bunny.

285
00:15:26.133 --> 00:15:27.498
I actually love this picture.

286
00:15:27.498 --> 00:15:31.743
[LAUGH] If I didn't like this picture,
I could come up here to the Review tab.

287
00:15:31.743 --> 00:15:36.123
You can see I have the Reject or
Accept and I can say do I want this.

288
00:15:36.123 --> 00:15:40.293
Well, maybe I don't want that and
then I can reject that change.

289
00:15:40.293 --> 00:15:43.330
You can use the next and the previous.

290
00:15:43.330 --> 00:15:47.640
Instead of physically clicking on them,
I can say yes, I want this, or no,

291
00:15:47.640 --> 00:15:48.820
I don't want this.

292
00:15:48.820 --> 00:15:51.250
Click on the boxes, turn them on or off.

293
00:15:51.250 --> 00:15:54.200
It's pretty much all the same thing, but
it's really neat how you can say well,

294
00:15:54.200 --> 00:15:55.930
what's the next thing that happened?

295
00:15:55.930 --> 00:15:58.650
>> Yeah, those can be really handy
when you got a long presentation and

296
00:15:58.650 --> 00:16:02.410
you got one change on slide four, but
the next change is until slide 27.

297
00:16:02.410 --> 00:16:03.182
>> Exactly.

298
00:16:03.182 --> 00:16:05.640
>> And you just sit there and go one
slide at a time looking for changes.

299
00:16:05.640 --> 00:16:07.978
Or you could just day, why don't
you jump to the next change for me?

300
00:16:07.978 --> 00:16:08.648
>> Great example.

301
00:16:08.648 --> 00:16:11.416
[LAUGH] Since I only have five slides,

302
00:16:11.416 --> 00:16:15.490
clicking on each slide is
not going to be very long.

303
00:16:15.490 --> 00:16:17.260
But yes,
multiple slides would be really great.

304
00:16:17.260 --> 00:16:21.759
So what did Joey do, he went ahead or
that was actually from the collection that

305
00:16:21.759 --> 00:16:26.800
l have before that it's associated with
Joey even though really Justin did it.

306
00:16:26.800 --> 00:16:31.350
And then you can see that he deleted
this one and inserted that text,

307
00:16:31.350 --> 00:16:37.420
l can go through each one and check all
these boxes off to see who did what, when.

308
00:16:37.420 --> 00:16:40.660
And it's really nice to be able to see and

309
00:16:40.660 --> 00:16:46.130
compare the different versions of my
slides, and then know what's going on.

310
00:16:46.130 --> 00:16:51.330
And I still have control of whether
I want to keep his changes or

311
00:16:51.330 --> 00:16:53.280
not keep his changes,
reject those changes.

312
00:16:53.280 --> 00:16:58.360
And you can see that the little box on the
slide of where he deleted that slide and

313
00:16:58.360 --> 00:16:59.170
everything like that.

314
00:16:59.170 --> 00:16:59.930
I love this feature.

315
00:16:59.930 --> 00:17:01.110
I think it's really, really handy.

316
00:17:01.110 --> 00:17:04.120
Because there's a lot of times
where I don't know what you did.

317
00:17:04.120 --> 00:17:09.110
And if you don't comment every single
thing that you, I'm talking to you, Joey.

318
00:17:09.110 --> 00:17:09.860
>> Joey, okay.

319
00:17:09.860 --> 00:17:11.750
[LAUGH]
>> Joey didn't tell me exactly

320
00:17:11.750 --> 00:17:12.265
what he did.

321
00:17:12.265 --> 00:17:13.925
At least I have that compare option.

322
00:17:13.925 --> 00:17:15.101
And then I can choose.

323
00:17:15.101 --> 00:17:18.110
And I think it's a really great
feature for collaborating.

324
00:17:18.110 --> 00:17:22.720
The old school way, and a little bit more
manual of comparing your results and

325
00:17:22.720 --> 00:17:24.570
being able to accept or reject.

326
00:17:24.570 --> 00:17:25.580
>> All right, Vonne.

327
00:17:25.580 --> 00:17:27.270
Great look there at collaboration.

328
00:17:27.270 --> 00:17:29.590
Really showing us what we
can do with PowerPoint.

329
00:17:29.590 --> 00:17:30.850
Because as you said at the beginning,

330
00:17:30.850 --> 00:17:33.135
a lot of times we might
be working on our own.

331
00:17:33.135 --> 00:17:35.925
But there's many times that we're
gonna be working with colleagues,

332
00:17:35.925 --> 00:17:37.395
business partners, what have you.

333
00:17:37.395 --> 00:17:41.525
Trying to come to a common goal or
working on the same presentation.

334
00:17:41.525 --> 00:17:43.675
So now we know how we can
send comments back and

335
00:17:43.675 --> 00:17:46.270
forth as we progress through our project.

336
00:17:46.270 --> 00:17:50.540
And then we can even compare two different
versions of a slide show to make sure we

337
00:17:50.540 --> 00:17:51.420
didn't miss anything.

338
00:17:51.420 --> 00:17:55.350
Or look for things that were changed
that maybe weren't commented, and

339
00:17:55.350 --> 00:17:56.280
we might not have noticed.

340
00:17:56.280 --> 00:17:57.680
So we thank you for that Vonne.

341
00:17:57.680 --> 00:17:59.260
Fantastic stuff there.

342
00:17:59.260 --> 00:18:01.760
All right, hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching this one.

343
00:18:01.760 --> 00:18:05.150
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Joey Fatone.

344
00:18:05.150 --> 00:18:06.113
>> And I'm Justin Timberlake.

345
00:18:06.113 --> 00:18:07.868
>> And we'll see you next time.

346
00:18:07.868 --> 00:18:10.700
[MUSIC]

347
00:18:10.700 --> 00:18:16.520
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike look at using OneDrive to collaborate on a PowerPoint presentation. They demonstrate uploading a presentation to the cloud, and various ways to give others access.
episodes.title: Collaborate in the Cloud
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.579
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
Im your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.579 --> 00:00:05.894
>> [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:05.894 --> 00:00:08.413
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.413 --> 00:00:10.148
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.148 --> 00:00:15.770
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here in IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:15.770 --> 00:00:20.149
I'm your host Mike Roderick and today we
are doing our advanced PowerPoint 2016.

7
00:00:20.149 --> 00:00:24.259
In this episode we're gonna be learning
how to collaborate In the cloud.

8
00:00:24.259 --> 00:00:28.068
Now, I brought my gear, I was ready
to jump in our hot air balloon, but

9
00:00:28.068 --> 00:00:30.210
those were evidently the wrong cloud.

10
00:00:30.210 --> 00:00:33.550
So here to help us and explain what the
heck it means to collaborate in the cloud

11
00:00:33.550 --> 00:00:35.120
is Ms Von Smith, welcome back Von.

12
00:00:35.120 --> 00:00:37.437
>> Thank you,
I'm glad you're geared up and ready to go.

13
00:00:37.437 --> 00:00:39.350
[LAUGH]
>> I was excited too.

14
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:42.181
>> Well don't worry,
we'll be using you in this whole episode.

15
00:00:42.181 --> 00:00:42.800
>> Okay.
>> So we're going to be

16
00:00:42.800 --> 00:00:43.760
collaborating with you.

17
00:00:43.760 --> 00:00:47.267
We're gonna float around in PowerPoint and
see what we can do together.

18
00:00:47.267 --> 00:00:51.772
So, and that's the whole point of this
episode is to show how we can collaborate

19
00:00:51.772 --> 00:00:53.100
in real time.

20
00:00:53.100 --> 00:00:56.710
Let's say I have somebody that I'm working
on a PowerPoint presentation with and

21
00:00:56.710 --> 00:01:01.660
their in a satellite office in another
city, but we both have Office 365,

22
00:01:01.660 --> 00:01:03.820
we both have PowerPoint.

23
00:01:03.820 --> 00:01:06.240
And I want to be able to work with them,

24
00:01:06.240 --> 00:01:08.710
like they were sitting
in the room next to me.

25
00:01:08.710 --> 00:01:12.080
Talking about our slides,
and editing things together.

26
00:01:12.080 --> 00:01:17.085
And we can do that, because Microsoft
has really kind of amped up their.

27
00:01:17.085 --> 00:01:22.445
Collaborating in that real time through
the use of their One Drive technology or

28
00:01:22.445 --> 00:01:23.645
service.

29
00:01:23.645 --> 00:01:26.193
There's also you have other things,
you have Skype and everything.

30
00:01:26.193 --> 00:01:30.330
But we're gonna be focusing specifically
on working within the application

31
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:32.220
through OneDrive.

32
00:01:32.220 --> 00:01:35.801
And so
OneDrive is that kinda ethereal [LAUGH]

33
00:01:35.801 --> 00:01:36.310
>> [LAUGH]

34
00:01:36.310 --> 00:01:38.529
>> Cloud-based storage device, or

35
00:01:38.529 --> 00:01:39.677
storage system,

36
00:01:39.677 --> 00:01:44.930
that we can use to be able to put things
up in there into that storage section.

37
00:01:44.930 --> 00:01:48.030
And then we can share it
out with other users and

38
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:50.380
that's exactly what we're going to do.

39
00:01:50.380 --> 00:01:52.050
>> Fantastic, all right,
how do we get started?

40
00:01:52.050 --> 00:01:56.000
>> Well, we're gonna go ahead and
take off by jumping into PowerPoint,

41
00:01:56.000 --> 00:01:59.400
jump into our little basket,
right, in out hot air balloon.

42
00:01:59.400 --> 00:02:03.690
And we're going to open up a file
that I have on my desktop, right now.

43
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:05.740
This is on my local computer.

44
00:02:05.740 --> 00:02:10.160
So now, what I need to do is I need to
go ahead and get this into my OneDrive

45
00:02:10.160 --> 00:02:14.756
account and then from there I'll be
able to go ahead and do my sharing out.

46
00:02:14.756 --> 00:02:18.960
But I would like to just do
a small side not right now.

47
00:02:18.960 --> 00:02:22.250
Is that I am using my OneDrive for
business.

48
00:02:22.250 --> 00:02:27.200
On a Windows operating machine, you do
have, installed with the operating system,

49
00:02:27.200 --> 00:02:31.940
you have the OneDrive account, your
personal account that you could use for

50
00:02:31.940 --> 00:02:33.830
that cloud storage.

51
00:02:33.830 --> 00:02:36.720
And so, I just wanna give you
a quick heads-up on that.

52
00:02:36.720 --> 00:02:38.800
I'm just gonna pull up
my Start Menu on there.

53
00:02:38.800 --> 00:02:40.020
You can see there's OneDrive.

54
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:42.530
But then there's OneDrive for
Business, and

55
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:45.670
that's the one that I'm
putting my files up into.

56
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:50.150
So we're going to do that,
we can do it in two ways.

57
00:02:50.150 --> 00:02:54.940
You can go ahead and do a File Save As,
and then change your location,

58
00:02:54.940 --> 00:02:57.010
to go ahead and put it in OneDrive.

59
00:02:57.010 --> 00:02:59.190
That will go ahead and
put it there just fine.

60
00:02:59.190 --> 00:03:02.370
You could also go into
the Share section here, and

61
00:03:02.370 --> 00:03:04.680
it's saying,
I do want to share it with people.

62
00:03:04.680 --> 00:03:09.250
And it's giving me a quick little overview
of we're gonna save it to OneDrive and

63
00:03:09.250 --> 00:03:13.100
then I'll go ahead and
help you share out your document.

64
00:03:13.100 --> 00:03:16.400
And it's gonna pull up our Share task
pane that we'll see in a second.

65
00:03:16.400 --> 00:03:20.430
But you could go either way,
so let's go here.

66
00:03:20.430 --> 00:03:21.740
And the funny thing is
once you go ahead and

67
00:03:21.740 --> 00:03:24.870
say, yeah go ahead and save it to the
cloud it takes you right back to Save As.

68
00:03:24.870 --> 00:03:27.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you're kinda going around and

69
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:31.880
I would like to make sure that I'm in my
OneDrive account that I have connected to.

70
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:36.370
I'm going to name this formatting
slides and themes are share.

71
00:03:36.370 --> 00:03:41.350
To clarify that this is going up into my
shared account or my OneDrive account.

72
00:03:41.350 --> 00:03:44.130
Going ahead and
it's getting everything ready for me.

73
00:03:44.130 --> 00:03:46.460
And now since I had gone
through that share with people,

74
00:03:46.460 --> 00:03:47.900
it's kinda set me back at this point.

75
00:03:47.900 --> 00:03:52.510
And says, well now I'm gonna go ahead and
help you get those sharing links and

76
00:03:52.510 --> 00:03:55.350
send invitations to people
that you want to include.

77
00:03:55.350 --> 00:03:58.914
And so it brings up that Share pane
over there on the right hand side.

78
00:03:58.914 --> 00:04:02.727
But if you had gone by that just Save As
and didn't go through that Save,

79
00:04:02.727 --> 00:04:06.224
it's right up here on the top above
a ribbon of where I can say yep,

80
00:04:06.224 --> 00:04:10.370
I wanna go ahead and share,
it brings that right up for you.

81
00:04:10.370 --> 00:04:12.560
Now, there's a couple ways
we could go ahead and

82
00:04:12.560 --> 00:04:15.850
invite people in, right from PowerPoint.

83
00:04:15.850 --> 00:04:19.870
We can email this presentation to
people within our global address list.

84
00:04:19.870 --> 00:04:21.650
And this is all connected
to our Outlook account.

85
00:04:21.650 --> 00:04:24.700
So you will you have to have Outlook setup

86
00:04:24.700 --> 00:04:27.890
to do this specific step
that I'm going to show you.

87
00:04:27.890 --> 00:04:29.650
But if you don't use Outlook.

88
00:04:29.650 --> 00:04:35.170
What if I'm using Gmail or some other type
of Cloud based Internets or not internet,

89
00:04:35.170 --> 00:04:39.930
email service you could go ahead and get a
shareable link that you could go ahead and

90
00:04:39.930 --> 00:04:43.250
find and get that link into your Gmail.

91
00:04:43.250 --> 00:04:46.570
I will say right now,
it's like well why isn't this showing?

92
00:04:46.570 --> 00:04:52.070
It will, I found that if it doesn't pop up
automatically with a get shareable link,

93
00:04:52.070 --> 00:04:56.830
which it will, I found sometimes if I
close PowerPoint and it opens file up,

94
00:04:56.830 --> 00:04:58.380
it kind of resets itself.

95
00:04:58.380 --> 00:05:02.030
So, we'll get back to that get
sharable link in just a second.

96
00:05:02.030 --> 00:05:05.980
But now what we're going to is we're
going to invite other people to

97
00:05:05.980 --> 00:05:08.080
our PowerPoint party.

98
00:05:08.080 --> 00:05:10.850
We're going to invite Lance into this.

99
00:05:10.850 --> 00:05:12.468
And I will get to you as well, Mike.

100
00:05:12.468 --> 00:05:13.620
>> Okay.
>> You're gonna be joining in.

101
00:05:13.620 --> 00:05:16.790
It's just,
I haven't sent your invitation yet, so.

102
00:05:16.790 --> 00:05:19.002
We're going to go ahead and
click on this, and

103
00:05:19.002 --> 00:05:22.817
it is going to connect to my global

So I could see that you've
made some changes and

326
00:17:21.416 --> 00:17:25.187
this is where you could be inserting
comments as well and we can use.

327
00:17:25.187 --> 00:17:28.142
And that's kinda like
establishing a workflow or

328
00:17:28.142 --> 00:17:30.755
like how we're going
to talk to each other.

329
00:17:30.755 --> 00:17:35.809
Like, okay, I really want us to use
comments to communicate and everything.

330
00:17:35.809 --> 00:17:39.248
You can see that while he's changing,
there's parts that are highlighting.

331
00:17:39.248 --> 00:17:43.132
Like it's highlighting right here that
somebody's doing something over here and

332
00:17:43.132 --> 00:17:44.638
a guest contributor is on this.

333
00:17:44.638 --> 00:17:49.935
So you could see that where people are at,
not just by on what the slide is,

334
00:17:49.935 --> 00:17:54.390
but what area they're in on the slide,
which we really need.

335
00:17:54.390 --> 00:17:58.975
I do wanna switch over to Lance again, for
just a second because let's go ahead and

336
00:17:58.975 --> 00:18:01.514
see that Lance can see
everybody that's in.

337
00:18:01.514 --> 00:18:04.649
Here we've got our Mike and Mike in here.

338
00:18:04.649 --> 00:18:09.429
[LAUGH] I'm going to go ahead and
close out my changes to this, but

339
00:18:09.429 --> 00:18:13.955
remember, I'm still in the browser
from my Lance account.

340
00:18:13.955 --> 00:18:18.450
And the neat thing is that I could go
ahead and continue to edit online.

341
00:18:18.450 --> 00:18:21.990
Let's just say for some reason, I didn't
want to be in the product anymore.

342
00:18:21.990 --> 00:18:23.941
And I could go ahead and continue and

343
00:18:23.941 --> 00:18:26.550
I can still see all
the changes that are in here.

344
00:18:26.550 --> 00:18:30.760
I can see that there are two
other people that are talking.

345
00:18:30.760 --> 00:18:33.090
And the other neat thing
is if I'm using online,

346
00:18:33.090 --> 00:18:38.620
is I can use the chat function over here,
there we go.

347
00:18:38.620 --> 00:18:42.237
It just had to take him a second
to go ahead and join in.

348
00:18:42.237 --> 00:18:45.323
And then if I'm editing
in the PowerPoint online,

349
00:18:45.323 --> 00:18:48.356
we could chat this way
instead of doing comments.

350
00:18:48.356 --> 00:18:50.120
So I could say like, hello.

351
00:18:50.120 --> 00:18:55.745
And I can say, and I can see right there
that GC, that guest contributor, as Mike.

352
00:18:55.745 --> 00:18:58.940
He's talking to me as well and so
we could always communicate this way.

353
00:18:58.940 --> 00:19:03.700
So that might be another advantage or
just a different way of doing things.

354
00:19:03.700 --> 00:19:07.220
If you wanted to kinda have
this type of IM'ing and

355
00:19:07.220 --> 00:19:11.180
communication, rather than through
the actual comments in the slides.

356
00:19:11.180 --> 00:19:14.480
But you see that the chat won't
be saved when you close a file.

357
00:19:14.480 --> 00:19:18.782
It's kind of like a one time, like
a session variable, like we're just doing

358
00:19:18.782 --> 00:19:22.964
it for this particular session that
we're talking online with each other.

359
00:19:22.964 --> 00:19:25.341
And so I wanted to point that part out.

360
00:19:25.341 --> 00:19:29.602
So you can see that there's a lot of
really neat things that we could do

361
00:19:29.602 --> 00:19:34.470
as a group to collaborate together when
using our PowerPoint presentations.

362
00:19:35.700 --> 00:19:40.935
But I would like to go ahead and
talk a little bit about me back as Joey,

363
00:19:40.935 --> 00:19:43.295
as the owner of this document.

364
00:19:43.295 --> 00:19:45.283
What if I, I'm done.

365
00:19:45.283 --> 00:19:46.875
Like I don't need your
contributions anymore.

366
00:19:46.875 --> 00:19:47.892
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

367
00:19:47.892 --> 00:19:50.750
I don't want you to be able to
do any of the changes anymore.

368
00:19:50.750 --> 00:19:54.334
And maybe it's like, okay,
thank you so much Lance, but

369
00:19:54.334 --> 00:19:56.172
I'm done with your sharing.

370
00:19:56.172 --> 00:20:00.059
I want to stop sharing this
file with you because maybe,

371
00:20:00.059 --> 00:20:03.212
we're finished, we finished our product.

372
00:20:03.212 --> 00:20:05.794
So you don't kinda wanna
leave any loose ends.

373
00:20:05.794 --> 00:20:08.033
>> Or you didn't like my style decisions.

374
00:20:08.033 --> 00:20:09.018
It's really what it is.

375
00:20:09.018 --> 00:20:12.054
>> Yeah,
that probably would be the case [LAUGH].

376
00:20:12.054 --> 00:20:14.685
I've seen them [LAUGH].

377
00:20:14.685 --> 00:20:19.960
So I wanted to go ahead and show you that,
let's jump back over to Joey.

378
00:20:19.960 --> 00:20:22.552
And I'm going to say, yes,

379
00:20:22.552 --> 00:20:28.507
just to make that last change as
the owner, for whatever reason.

380
00:20:28.507 --> 00:20:29.874
And Mike.

381
00:20:29.874 --> 00:20:30.940
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

382
00:20:30.940 --> 00:20:32.564
>> So I can see that other change that

383
00:20:32.564 --> 00:20:33.321
Mike had done.

384
00:20:33.321 --> 00:20:35.813
And you can see that when it
was highlighted in that box,

385
00:20:35.813 --> 00:20:37.254
that you were doing something.

386
00:20:37.254 --> 00:20:39.417
So I'm going to close PowerPoint.

387
00:20:39.417 --> 00:20:41.369
And I'm gonna go ahead and

388
00:20:41.369 --> 00:20:47.405
get into my Office online account because
I need to get into my OneDrive account,

389
00:20:47.405 --> 00:20:52.231
and say, all right,
I wanna cut off the sharing capabilities.

390
00:20:52.231 --> 00:20:58.690
So, as the owner of this document,
I'm gonna go ahead and sign in as Joey.

391
00:20:58.690 --> 00:21:02.340
Here are all the different
things that Joey has access to.

392
00:21:02.340 --> 00:21:04.300
I'm going to click on OneDrive.

393
00:21:06.240 --> 00:21:09.968
And then from here,
it's pulling itself up.

394
00:21:12.233 --> 00:21:13.307
All right, so

395
00:21:13.307 --> 00:21:18.954
here's my file that does show that I
have shared this out with some people.

396
00:21:18.954 --> 00:21:22.040
If I click on the shared over
here on the right hand side.

397
00:21:22.040 --> 00:21:26.471
It's gonna bring up my pane, to say,
these are the people that I have access.

398
00:21:26.471 --> 00:21:29.504
And this is always a good thing to go
back to because maybe I shared out with

399
00:21:29.504 --> 00:21:32.470
somebody that I didn't even realize
that I gave them that share link.

400
00:21:32.470 --> 00:21:36.550
Cuz maybe they never contributed or did
anything, but I wanna just kinda tie this

401
00:21:36.550 --> 00:21:40.820
up and I wanna change the permissions
that people have access to.

402
00:21:40.820 --> 00:21:43.858
So I'm gonna click on change permissions,
and that link,

403
00:21:43.858 --> 00:21:47.584
this is a link that anyone can get cuz
maybe Mike gave it to somebody else.

404
00:21:47.584 --> 00:21:51.679
And I wouldn't even know that because
it is, it's like an open channel,

405
00:21:51.679 --> 00:21:52.677
if you wanna say.

406
00:21:52.677 --> 00:21:56.941
So I'm gonna cut off that open channel and
I can just go ahead and disable this link.

407
00:21:56.941 --> 00:21:59.671
And I'm going to remove the link and
that way,

408
00:21:59.671 --> 00:22:03.395
if Mike clicked on that link or
anybody else that had that link.

409
00:22:03.395 --> 00:22:05.941
They would not be able
to access this file,

410
00:22:05.941 --> 00:22:10.630
they're just gonna get like a warning,
like access denied or a 404 error.

411
00:22:10.630 --> 00:22:14.485
Some type of error to where it's saying,
no, we can't go in there.

412
00:22:14.485 --> 00:22:18.011
The other thing is, I don't really want
Lance to have access to it as well.

413
00:22:18.011 --> 00:22:21.293
So you could see, if I click on
the drop-down underneath his name,

414
00:22:21.293 --> 00:22:23.144
I could change it to just view-only.

415
00:22:23.144 --> 00:22:25.177
So he can still see it,
but he can't change it.

416
00:22:25.177 --> 00:22:27.565
Or I can just stop sharing altogether.

417
00:22:27.565 --> 00:22:29.716
And when I click stop sharing,

418
00:22:29.716 --> 00:22:34.431
now I'm going to be the only person
that has access to this file, and

419
00:22:34.431 --> 00:22:39.755
I can move on and say thank you so much
for contributing but now, we are done.

420
00:22:39.755 --> 00:22:45.412
The last little part that I wanted to
tell you about is the sharing privileges.

421
00:22:45.412 --> 00:22:50.143
When I had shared it out to Lance, it gave
up on the top that he could share this or

422
00:22:50.143 --> 00:22:52.670
invite other people to edit that as well.

423
00:22:52.670 --> 00:22:54.617
In your OneDrive admin,

424
00:22:54.617 --> 00:22:59.716
you have some settings in here that
you could if you wanted to say,

425
00:22:59.716 --> 00:23:05.111
all right, well, I don't want people
to go ahead and share past me.

426
00:23:05.111 --> 00:23:10.956
And that is down here,
if you scroll down just a little bit.

427
00:23:10.956 --> 00:23:12.277
It's getting there.

428
00:23:12.277 --> 00:23:14.013
Wait, I'm on the wrong section.

429
00:23:14.013 --> 00:23:20.930
[LAUGH] I'm like wait, let's go over here
to the left and click on the sharing part.

430
00:23:20.930 --> 00:23:24.220
Yes, so
the sharing capabilities of OneDrive.

431
00:23:24.220 --> 00:23:26.569
And you could go down, the one was here,

432
00:23:26.569 --> 00:23:29.831
it says let external users
share items they don't own.

433
00:23:29.831 --> 00:23:35.107
Because he, Lance was a contributor,
he wasn't the owner, so it's saying,

434
00:23:35.107 --> 00:23:40.176
okay, you don't want to, I'm the only
one that can give that capability.

435
00:23:40.176 --> 00:23:43.622
One other point that I have mentioned,
I said about the auto sharing.

436
00:23:43.622 --> 00:23:44.618
>> The auto saving.

437
00:23:44.618 --> 00:23:46.479
>> The auto save, yes, [LAUGH].

438
00:23:46.479 --> 00:23:48.147
The other S, [LAUGH].

439
00:23:48.147 --> 00:23:53.081
The auto saving, that is something
that you do have to have like,

440
00:23:53.081 --> 00:23:55.786
the most recent version of Office.

441
00:23:55.786 --> 00:23:59.289
And maybe by the time you're doing this,
you already have this feature.

442
00:23:59.289 --> 00:24:01.610
But for me, I don't have it.

443
00:24:01.610 --> 00:24:06.905
Let me just point it out in PowerPoint.

444
00:24:06.905 --> 00:24:09.923
And I'm going to go into my
PowerPoint options of Joey,

445
00:24:09.923 --> 00:24:14.020
just gonna go to open other presentation
so I can get into the options.

446
00:24:14.020 --> 00:24:16.815
You see here on the General section,

447
00:24:16.815 --> 00:24:22.689
there's not a section down here that says,
enable auto sharing for saving.

448
00:24:22.689 --> 00:24:28.176
And that's because this particular version
of Office or this particular version

449
00:24:28.176 --> 00:24:33.672
of PowerPoint, you see right here
version 1609 and there's a build number.

450
00:24:33.672 --> 00:24:37.915
Let me switch over here to JT,
this is Justin.

451
00:24:37.915 --> 00:24:39.740
Well, I call him JT.

452
00:24:39.740 --> 00:24:40.562
That's his nickname.

453
00:24:40.562 --> 00:24:41.770
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Or I guess my nickname.

454
00:24:41.770 --> 00:24:42.530
I'm Justin aren't I?

455
00:24:42.530 --> 00:24:43.180
>> Yes, that's right.

456
00:24:43.180 --> 00:24:46.170
>> Okay, so my nickname is Justin.

457
00:24:46.170 --> 00:24:50.610
Over here in my PowerPoint,
I do have that option.

458
00:24:51.770 --> 00:24:55.400
And this is because I kinda forced it to

459
00:24:55.400 --> 00:25:00.360
commit to the most recent
version of PowerPoint.

460
00:25:00.360 --> 00:25:03.962
And right here, look at the account,
see there's a different build number and

461
00:25:03.962 --> 00:25:06.563
I have a higher build number and
a higher version number.

462
00:25:06.563 --> 00:25:11.411
So if I go into my options here right
down there, real-time collaboration,

463
00:25:11.411 --> 00:25:15.250
when working with others
automatically save changes.

464
00:25:15.250 --> 00:25:20.820
And so this is set and
Justin's version but not in Joey's and

465
00:25:20.820 --> 00:25:27.890
that's where I made a quick little
Word document that explains and

466
00:25:27.890 --> 00:25:31.420
gives lengths to different websites
that kind of explain what this means,

467
00:25:31.420 --> 00:25:36.610
is that you have to set in
your Office 365 Admin Center.

468
00:25:36.610 --> 00:25:39.420
You have to go in to your
software download settings and

469
00:25:39.420 --> 00:25:43.150
set it to that every month,
so where it's updating itself

470
00:25:43.150 --> 00:25:46.730
every month because the default
settings is every four months.

471
00:25:46.730 --> 00:25:52.090
And so if you wait four months,
it'll eventually get you all the changes,

472
00:25:52.090 --> 00:25:55.750
but if you needed to do that,
you could always set it to that.

473
00:25:55.750 --> 00:26:00.533
And if that setting doesn't work, they
say that you can do a full uninstall of

474
00:26:00.533 --> 00:26:04.156
Office and then reinstall Office,
and it would force it.

475
00:26:04.156 --> 00:26:05.392
That's what I had to do.

476
00:26:05.392 --> 00:26:10.250
Now if you're in a networked environment
or a large organization, you might not

477
00:26:10.250 --> 00:26:14.980
have access to this particular function
within your Office 365 accounts.

478
00:26:14.980 --> 00:26:19.070
So if you don't see it, don't think
that you have something broken.

479
00:26:19.070 --> 00:26:22.750
It's just that you might have people
that are controlling you from higher up,

480
00:26:22.750 --> 00:26:23.392
if you wanna say.

481
00:26:23.392 --> 00:26:24.922
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're saying no,

482
00:26:24.922 --> 00:26:27.627
you can't mess with those settings.

483
00:26:27.627 --> 00:26:30.062
I do cover this in
the custom show's episode,

484
00:26:30.062 --> 00:26:34.190
where we talk about the different ways
that you can use the zoom capabilities.

485
00:26:34.190 --> 00:26:38.914
This is another one of it's kind of all
lumped together within your Office 365

486
00:26:38.914 --> 00:26:39.960
admin settings.

487
00:26:41.040 --> 00:26:43.390
>> I love both of those features honestly.

488
00:26:43.390 --> 00:26:46.740
The autosave, cuz if you're working
with somebody or you're making changes.

489
00:26:46.740 --> 00:26:47.620
You are like hey, did you see what I did?

490
00:26:47.620 --> 00:26:48.230
What do you think of that?

491
00:26:48.230 --> 00:26:49.720
Though I don't see them.

492
00:26:49.720 --> 00:26:51.200
That's right, I didn't save it.

493
00:26:51.200 --> 00:26:52.610
Let me save it real quick.

494
00:26:52.610 --> 00:26:55.080
And it's just a constant issue.

495
00:26:55.080 --> 00:26:55.720
So, I like that.

496
00:26:55.720 --> 00:26:57.100
And then the thing about sharing it.

497
00:26:57.100 --> 00:27:01.310
You know, I've shared it with you, but
I don't want you sharing it with somebody.

498
00:27:01.310 --> 00:27:04.570
It could be intellectual property,
it could be company specific, and

499
00:27:04.570 --> 00:27:08.800
there's a risk there of exposing
that data beyond what it should be.

500
00:27:08.800 --> 00:27:10.400
So, limiting who can share.

501
00:27:10.400 --> 00:27:12.710
Yes, I've shared it with you, but
that doesn't mean you can turn around and

502
00:27:12.710 --> 00:27:13.565
share it with somebody else.

503
00:27:13.565 --> 00:27:14.100
>> Mm-hm.

504
00:27:14.100 --> 00:27:17.170
>> I love both of those features,
so we thank you for that Vonne.

505
00:27:17.170 --> 00:27:20.700
Great explanations, great demonstrations
on the whole sharing process.

506
00:27:20.700 --> 00:27:23.950
Being able to collaborate,
take advantage of the cloud, and

507
00:27:23.950 --> 00:27:27.390
work with people that aren't located
in the same building, the same city,

508
00:27:27.390 --> 00:27:31.500
the same country as you, fantastic stuff,
so we thank you for that.

509
00:27:31.500 --> 00:27:33.990
We hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

510
00:27:33.990 --> 00:27:37.090
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been you host, Mike Rodrick.

511
00:27:37.090 --> 00:27:37.766
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

512
00:27:37.766 --> 00:27:39.729
>> And we'll see you next time.

513
00:27:39.729 --> 00:27:45.741
[MUSIC]

514
00:27:45.741 --> 00:27:48.671
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike discuss creating custom shows in PowerPoint. They demonstrate how to rehearse timings, adding hyperlinks and action buttons. They also show how to use one presentation for multiple groups by creating custom or 'sub' shows within a presentation, and how to use the zoom function.
episodes.title: Custom Shows
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.250 --> 00:00:06.482
Welcome IT PRO TV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.482 --> 00:00:08.274
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.274 --> 00:00:11.759
>> You're watching IT PRO TV.

4
00:00:11.759 --> 00:00:15.653
>> Hello welcome to another
exiting episode here at IT PRO TV.

5
00:00:15.653 --> 00:00:20.138
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and today
we're doing our advanced Powerpoint 2016.

6
00:00:20.138 --> 00:00:24.496
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be taking a look at custom shows.

7
00:00:24.496 --> 00:00:27.890
Now you might think, well wait a second
Mike aren't all of my shows custom?

8
00:00:27.890 --> 00:00:31.030
We start with a blank presentation and
build it from scratch.

9
00:00:31.030 --> 00:00:33.571
Well that might be true there
are some really cool features.

10
00:00:33.571 --> 00:00:38.420
We can take advantage of in PowerPoint
that give us the ability to do what we're

11
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:40.040
gonna call custom shows.

12
00:00:40.040 --> 00:00:42.410
So here to explain what
the heck that means and

13
00:00:42.410 --> 00:00:44.230
how we can do it is Miss Vonne Smith.

14
00:00:44.230 --> 00:00:44.990
Welcome back, Vonne.

15
00:00:44.990 --> 00:00:46.046
>> Thank you very much.

16
00:00:46.046 --> 00:00:50.452
And yes we are creating custom shows
in the sense of how we're going to be

17
00:00:50.452 --> 00:00:52.298
delivering our slide shows.

18
00:00:52.298 --> 00:00:54.580
Not necessarily building them.

19
00:00:54.580 --> 00:01:00.170
So we're gonna take our customly built
show and then create our presentation.

20
00:01:00.170 --> 00:01:01.730
Actually I think I just
said that backwards.

21
00:01:01.730 --> 00:01:03.588
We are going to- [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> Well it's a custom built show.

22
00:01:03.588 --> 00:01:05.797
We're gonna also do custom presentations.

23
00:01:05.797 --> 00:01:07.209
>> Yes, well, show presentation,

24
00:01:07.209 --> 00:01:09.456
I think we're just gonna
use those interchangeably.

25
00:01:09.456 --> 00:01:10.037
>> Okay.

26
00:01:10.037 --> 00:01:12.290
>> So
we made one now we have to deliver it.

27
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:13.233
What are we going to do?

28
00:01:13.233 --> 00:01:17.606
So maybe I have a slide show
that is focusing on a couple

29
00:01:17.606 --> 00:01:21.000
different Audiences for instance.

30
00:01:21.000 --> 00:01:25.864
Like maybe I went ahead and made one big
slideshow that has something that has

31
00:01:25.864 --> 00:01:30.729
to do with the marketing team, and
the sales team and the development team.

32
00:01:30.729 --> 00:01:34.859
And when I'm delivering a presentation
to just the development team

33
00:01:34.859 --> 00:01:37.846
they might not really want
to know all of the ins and

34
00:01:37.846 --> 00:01:41.566
outs of what maybe the marketing
team is gonna want to know..

35
00:01:41.566 --> 00:01:44.293
But if I'm giving a presentation

What a Summary Zoom is going to do is
it's gonna create you a brand new slide.

485
00:24:59.830 --> 00:25:04.590
If you use the Section Zoom, it's going to
use your present slide that you're in and

486
00:25:04.590 --> 00:25:05.180
then add it.

487
00:25:05.180 --> 00:25:09.010
But it's going to look very similar,
so those are the biggest difference.

488
00:25:09.010 --> 00:25:12.910
Is new slide created for
you versus it's just gonna go ahead and

489
00:25:12.910 --> 00:25:16.340
put the pieces for you to be able to
build it however you want to build it

490
00:25:16.340 --> 00:25:17.390
within your current slide.

491
00:25:17.390 --> 00:25:22.546
So I'm gonna start with the Section Zoom
and notice it is saying link to a section.

492
00:25:22.546 --> 00:25:24.070
Got to have the sections.

493
00:25:25.220 --> 00:25:27.420
These are the different sections
that I have designated.

494
00:25:27.420 --> 00:25:31.110
So what are the ones I want buttons for
those different pieces?

495
00:25:31.110 --> 00:25:34.882
So I can select,
I want Section 2, 3, and 4.

496
00:25:34.882 --> 00:25:38.470
My Sunsets, Cats and New York City.

497
00:25:38.470 --> 00:25:43.767
I click Insert and
it adds the slides like a little image of

498
00:25:43.767 --> 00:25:51.350
each of hose sections first slides
right into my slide my slide here.

499
00:25:51.350 --> 00:25:55.096
I can then move them around just like
I would if they were pictures and

500
00:25:55.096 --> 00:25:56.751
I'm going to kind of go here.

501
00:25:56.751 --> 00:26:02.071
I'm going to try to make myself not
get to obsessive about the alignment.

502
00:26:02.071 --> 00:26:02.980
>> Good stuff.

503
00:26:02.980 --> 00:26:03.627
>> Okay, that's enough,
that's enough [LAUGH].

504
00:26:03.627 --> 00:26:07.406
And so you can see that's
the first slide of each section.

505
00:26:07.406 --> 00:26:10.449
Let me show you what happens when
you go ahead and run it from,

506
00:26:10.449 --> 00:26:12.540
I'll run it from the beginning.

507
00:26:12.540 --> 00:26:13.870
So I start the show.

508
00:26:13.870 --> 00:26:16.210
Here's my next slide, so
what are we gonna talk about?

509
00:26:16.210 --> 00:26:18.920
Let's go ahead and
talk about New York City.

510
00:26:18.920 --> 00:26:23.990
And as soon as I click on New York City,
see how it zooms in?

511
00:26:23.990 --> 00:26:25.147
>> Hence the name zoom.

512
00:26:25.147 --> 00:26:26.050
>> Isn't that fancy?

513
00:26:26.050 --> 00:26:28.801
>> I like it.
>> Yes, it's so simple, but it's just,

514
00:26:28.801 --> 00:26:31.016
I don't know, I just really like it.

515
00:26:31.016 --> 00:26:33.519
So here's New York and now I'm just
clicking through as I normally would.

516
00:26:33.519 --> 00:26:35.128
So here's my next slide.

517
00:26:35.128 --> 00:26:36.694
Here's my next slide.

518
00:26:36.694 --> 00:26:38.543
Here's my next slide.

519
00:26:38.543 --> 00:26:39.976
Where do I go next?

520
00:26:39.976 --> 00:26:45.397
It zooms me back out and puts me right
back to the slide I started from.

521
00:26:45.397 --> 00:26:46.137
>> Very clever.

522
00:26:46.137 --> 00:26:47.188
>> Right, yeah.

523
00:26:47.188 --> 00:26:51.400
And then if I wanted to go to Cats,
we can go through the different cats and

524
00:26:51.400 --> 00:26:55.420
then it will zoom right back out to
my next slide and so on and so forth.

525
00:26:55.420 --> 00:26:59.970
So it's a nice way of organizing
different areas of your presentation that

526
00:26:59.970 --> 00:27:01.050
always kind of goes back.

527
00:27:01.050 --> 00:27:04.930
So think about if you were going
through the different departments,

528
00:27:04.930 --> 00:27:06.110
you'd just click on it.

529
00:27:06.110 --> 00:27:08.910
You go in through that and you come
right back out and that's all you need.

530
00:27:08.910 --> 00:27:12.300
You almost don't even need
like a whole another slide,

531
00:27:12.300 --> 00:27:13.630
you just right here talking.

532
00:27:13.630 --> 00:27:16.570
I mean of course, you can still do more
slides, but then you would have to,

533
00:27:16.570 --> 00:27:21.145
I am just hitting the Escape key to
take me out of the show altogether.

534
00:27:21.145 --> 00:27:24.095
You could then create,
you could add another button for

535
00:27:24.095 --> 00:27:28.565
a hyperlink that would go
to like the last slide.

536
00:27:28.565 --> 00:27:32.882
If I wanted to jump to the very last
slide, but it's not in a section, is it?

537
00:27:32.882 --> 00:27:35.055
I think it actually is
in a section [LAUGH].

538
00:27:35.055 --> 00:27:39.594
But let's pretend that there isn't
a section called final slide,

539
00:27:39.594 --> 00:27:41.913
because you can go into your zoom.

540
00:27:41.913 --> 00:27:44.165
And you can go into a Slide Zoom, so

541
00:27:44.165 --> 00:27:48.220
it's just jumping to a specific
slide in your presentation.

542
00:27:49.320 --> 00:27:53.450
Again, pretend my last slide did not
actually have a designated section on it.

543
00:27:53.450 --> 00:27:56.410
Or even if it does, it doesn't matter
because right here if I'm using this

544
00:27:56.410 --> 00:28:01.940
particular choice of zoom, I could say
let's go ahead and jump to the last slide.

545
00:28:01.940 --> 00:28:03.980
It adds it just the same.

546
00:28:03.980 --> 00:28:05.990
Notice it doesn't have like
a little box around it.

547
00:28:05.990 --> 00:28:09.070
But I think that's actually because
that's the way the slide is formatted, so

548
00:28:09.070 --> 00:28:09.615
nevermind.

549
00:28:09.615 --> 00:28:11.850
[LAUGH] Let's go ahead and

550
00:28:11.850 --> 00:28:17.010
run this from this slide right here and
we will go from this current slide.

551
00:28:17.010 --> 00:28:18.760
And you could go through your zooms.

552
00:28:18.760 --> 00:28:23.580
And then if I jump down to this slide,
it'll take me to that final slide.

553
00:28:23.580 --> 00:28:25.490
And then it will go ahead and
end the show.

554
00:28:25.490 --> 00:28:27.760
Cuz it's only taking me
to a specific slide and

555
00:28:27.760 --> 00:28:29.220
then going forward from that place.

556
00:28:29.220 --> 00:28:35.705
So that's a little different than adding
the Section Zoom and the Slide Zoom.

557
00:28:35.705 --> 00:28:38.854
And just the last option,
just to show you what it does,

558
00:28:38.854 --> 00:28:42.900
if you go to the Insert tab and
go to Links, I'm back on slide two.

559
00:28:42.900 --> 00:28:48.580
Just to have a starting point for where
l want to go, if l go to Summary Zoom,

560
00:28:48.580 --> 00:28:52.700
this is where it's automatically gonna
find the section slides that l have.

561
00:28:52.700 --> 00:28:57.860
And there is my conclusion slide and
l want to say yep, go ahead and add it.

562
00:28:57.860 --> 00:29:01.041
Let's go ahead and insert, you can see
that it gave me a whole new slide.

563
00:29:01.041 --> 00:29:07.122
And it did make an actual summary section
for me to do and then I could go ahead and

564
00:29:07.122 --> 00:29:12.300
give it it's own title, I could
format it and I can move it around.

565
00:29:12.300 --> 00:29:16.560
So it's just a starting point
from when it will create it and

566
00:29:16.560 --> 00:29:17.900
increased that whole new slide.

567
00:29:17.900 --> 00:29:20.030
And you can still customize it,
moving things around,

568
00:29:20.030 --> 00:29:24.600
you can make things smaller or bigger
however you want it to go forward with it.

569
00:29:24.600 --> 00:29:27.190
So, love that new feature,
it's very awesome.

570
00:29:27.190 --> 00:29:27.900
>> Very, very cool.

571
00:29:27.900 --> 00:29:29.710
All right now, Vonne,
one last thing, I guess.

572
00:29:29.710 --> 00:29:32.470
Can you show us how we can
get that if we don't have it?

573
00:29:32.470 --> 00:29:35.630
>> Yes, so I had to check this.

574
00:29:35.630 --> 00:29:39.880
And cuz I just installed Office
not that long ago on this machine.

575
00:29:39.880 --> 00:29:43.980
So I'm like, how can I not have
the most recent version of Office

576
00:29:43.980 --> 00:29:47.390
installed in my computer, and
I have these in the show notes.

577
00:29:47.390 --> 00:29:51.350
So I have the links to some of
the places that I found online where

578
00:29:51.350 --> 00:29:52.280
I found the information.

579
00:29:52.280 --> 00:29:58.010
But you have to go into your Office
365 Administration Center, and then

580
00:29:58.010 --> 00:30:02.090
you have to go to your Office software and
your software download settings.

581
00:30:02.090 --> 00:30:06.437
I was gonna go ahead and
just take you into this quickly.

582
00:30:06.437 --> 00:30:10.790
If I could go ahead and
log into my 365 account.

583
00:30:10.790 --> 00:30:12.270
So here I'm at my login screen,

584
00:30:12.270 --> 00:30:16.980
so I'm gonna go ahead and
sign into my Office 365 account.

585
00:30:16.980 --> 00:30:19.383
And then I'm going to wait for
it for just a second.

586
00:30:19.383 --> 00:30:23.819
Okay, so now I'm into my welcome
screen for my Office 365 for

587
00:30:23.819 --> 00:30:26.440
my Justin Timberlake account.

588
00:30:26.440 --> 00:30:29.660
I'm going to go into
the Admin section right here.

589
00:30:29.660 --> 00:30:31.610
It will open up in a new tab.

590
00:30:33.100 --> 00:30:34.750
So now I'm in my Admin center.

591
00:30:34.750 --> 00:30:39.640
We're going to go over here to where
it says the Office software and

592
00:30:39.640 --> 00:30:42.520
we're going to go into
the software download settings.

593
00:30:44.600 --> 00:30:48.390
And we have our little box that comes up
and it's going to go through everything.

594
00:30:48.390 --> 00:30:49.790
The thing you need to look for

595
00:30:49.790 --> 00:30:53.240
here is that how often do you
want users to get features.

596
00:30:53.240 --> 00:30:55.430
And you want to choose it to every month.

597
00:30:55.430 --> 00:30:58.490
When I had mine,
it was set to every four months,

598
00:30:58.490 --> 00:31:01.550
which is it says, the deferred channel.

599
00:31:01.550 --> 00:31:03.420
I think it was on by default.

600
00:31:03.420 --> 00:31:05.008
That's how mine was set up.

601
00:31:05.008 --> 00:31:07.720
So you're thinking every four months.

602
00:31:07.720 --> 00:31:11.440
Well, I thought I was on the most
recent version, I wasn't.

603
00:31:11.440 --> 00:31:15.594
I changed it to this every month and
then I reinstall, I didn't reinstall yet,

604
00:31:15.594 --> 00:31:19.128
I restarted my computer,
I did all my things, I logged back in, and

605
00:31:19.128 --> 00:31:20.431
it still wasn't there.

606
00:31:20.431 --> 00:31:24.060
So I was like well,
this is what it told me to do.

607
00:31:24.060 --> 00:31:27.020
So I did a little bit more searching and
it said that if it

608
00:31:27.020 --> 00:31:31.660
doesn't work automatically if you choose
this option, it's still not doing what

609
00:31:31.660 --> 00:31:36.650
I suggest is that you do a full
re-installation of the Office products.

610
00:31:36.650 --> 00:31:40.510
So I went in to my Add or
Remove programs, I went ahead and

611
00:31:40.510 --> 00:31:44.900
uninstall the full version
of Office from my computer.

612
00:31:44.900 --> 00:31:50.580
Came back into my Office 365 account,
click the download or install Office.

613
00:31:50.580 --> 00:31:53.975
I installed Office again and
everything was there.

614
00:31:53.975 --> 00:32:01.535
And it fixed, it worked itself out just
like the Google search told me to do.

615
00:32:01.535 --> 00:32:02.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> Which is nice and

616
00:32:02.240 --> 00:32:05.470
actually found it on Microsoft
community boards that would let

617
00:32:05.470 --> 00:32:07.410
me know that that's what I needed to do.

618
00:32:07.410 --> 00:32:11.800
And so if anybody has been watching and
how did you get that icons?

619
00:32:11.800 --> 00:32:13.400
See how it says insert an icon?

620
00:32:13.400 --> 00:32:16.510
This is another feature that was added and

621
00:32:16.510 --> 00:32:20.230
there's actually quite a few more
things in the PowerPoint options.

622
00:32:20.230 --> 00:32:23.270
That are new things that
I hadn't seen before,

623
00:32:23.270 --> 00:32:27.690
which actually we're going to be
talking about in another episode.

624
00:32:27.690 --> 00:32:34.770
When we get into collaboration of the auto
saving that wasn't in this account.

625
00:32:34.770 --> 00:32:37.290
It wasn't in the account that I'm
going to be demonstrating that from.

626
00:32:37.290 --> 00:32:40.848
Because I hadn't done this whole install,
re-update everything,

627
00:32:40.848 --> 00:32:42.365
re-update, is that a word?

628
00:32:42.365 --> 00:32:43.123
>> Re-update, it is, no.

629
00:32:43.123 --> 00:32:44.653
>> Okay [LAUGH].

630
00:32:44.653 --> 00:32:48.683
It is, so that was my fix, so
if you need to do that, double-check that,

631
00:32:48.683 --> 00:32:52.453
check the links in my notes and
you should be able to have zoom ready for

632
00:32:52.453 --> 00:32:54.940
your wonderful PowerPoint presentations.

633
00:32:54.940 --> 00:32:55.710
>> Awesome, Vonne.

634
00:32:55.710 --> 00:32:58.240
I tell you what we started the show,
it's like what do you mean custom shows?

635
00:32:58.240 --> 00:33:00.880
Now we all know what she
means by custom shows.

636
00:33:00.880 --> 00:33:04.900
Fantastic stuff, great features there,
great explanations and demos.

637
00:33:04.900 --> 00:33:07.176
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

638
00:33:07.176 --> 00:33:09.889
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

639
00:33:09.889 --> 00:33:11.032
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

640
00:33:11.032 --> 00:33:12.099
>> And we'll see you next time.

641
00:33:12.099 --> 00:33:18.975
[MUSIC]

642
00:33:18.975 --> 00:33:21.593
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike look at file metadata and other advanced file properties. They discuss adding tags and categories to help find a file. They demonstrate inspecting a document to look for off-slide content, notes or other information that we might want to remove. They also look at accessibility options, compatibility options, and how to protect a presentation.
episodes.title: Advanced File Properties
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:05.995
Welcome to ITPro.TV I'm your
host [INAUDIBLE] [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.995 --> 00:00:08.247
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.247 --> 00:00:10.776
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

4
00:00:10.776 --> 00:00:12.156
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:12.156 --> 00:00:15.561
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.561 --> 00:00:19.960
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and today we
are doing our Advanced Powerpoint 2016.

7
00:00:19.960 --> 00:00:21.738
And specifically in this episode,

8
00:00:21.738 --> 00:00:24.651
we are gonna be looking at
some advanced file properties.

9
00:00:24.651 --> 00:00:28.275
Here to guide us through and tell us
what they are, is Miss Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:28.275 --> 00:00:28.950
Welcome back Vonne.

11
00:00:28.950 --> 00:00:29.685
>> Hello.

12
00:00:29.685 --> 00:00:33.278
Yes, we're going to be talking
about hidden information.

13
00:00:33.278 --> 00:00:34.893
>> Hidden.
>> It's not really hidden, but

14
00:00:34.893 --> 00:00:37.307
it's probably something that
you don't see right away.

15
00:00:37.307 --> 00:00:40.520
Because anytime that we've
been talking about our files,

16
00:00:40.520 --> 00:00:43.219
we've been talking about
giving the file a name,

17
00:00:43.219 --> 00:00:46.574
a location of where we're going
to save it and the extension.

18
00:00:46.574 --> 00:00:51.058
We also talked about like the PPTX
versus PPSX, [LAUGH] it's a matter of

19
00:00:51.058 --> 00:00:54.782
file format, I was trying to
get those letters correct and

20
00:00:54.782 --> 00:00:59.418
those different types of files, but
there us a lot more information when

21
00:00:59.418 --> 00:01:04.490
working with files that is behind
the scenes, it's called metadata.

22
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:08.510
And this metadata can be very helpful for
you if you know one,

23
00:01:08.510 --> 00:01:11.920
where it is and two,
why you would even want to have it.

24
00:01:11.920 --> 00:01:17.520
So, I have file that we're going to be
using to add some information in, and

25
00:01:17.520 --> 00:01:23.560
this file specifically came from
Joey Fatone, not Justin Timberlake.

26
00:01:23.560 --> 00:01:26.066
How do I know that?
Well it says right here in the title slide

27
00:01:26.066 --> 00:01:27.048
said Joey Fatone.

28
00:01:27.048 --> 00:01:28.610
Well it's more than just that.

29
00:01:28.610 --> 00:01:30.731
You can find who created this file,

30
00:01:30.731 --> 00:01:34.349
when it was created,
when was the last time it was modified.

31
00:01:34.349 --> 00:01:38.361
And you can even add more
information to this file,

32
00:01:38.361 --> 00:01:42.744
in case you wanted to index
it in a more detailed manner,

33
00:01:42.744 --> 00:01:47.998
than just knowing the name of the file and
the location of the file.

34
00:01:47.998 --> 00:01:50.466
>> Yeah Vonne, so
where are we gonna find that information?

35
00:01:50.466 --> 00:01:53.417
>> Well the file properties
would be in the file tab.

36
00:01:53.417 --> 00:01:56.827
So [LAUGH] we're going to go into
the back stage view over here, and

37
00:01:56.827 --> 00:02:00.609
right on that info screen or the info
section that it comes on by default,

38
00:02:00.609 --> 00:02:02.160
here's my file properties.

39
00:02:02.160 --> 00:02:05.607
We're going to be going over all sorts
of the things over here on the left, but

40
00:02:05.607 --> 00:02:09.001
we're gonna go over to the right first
to show you that the file properties,

41
00:02:09.001 --> 00:02:11.359
this is where it has the size,
the number of slides.

42
00:02:11.359 --> 00:02:15.453
And you can see that it has a title,
which is the name of the file.

43
00:02:15.453 --> 00:02:18.051
But there's also some other
tags that have been added, or

44
00:02:18.051 --> 00:02:20.716
some other information that
has been added into this file.

45
00:02:20.716 --> 00:02:24.774
You can see the tags has Fuego and Bishop.

46
00:02:24.774 --> 00:02:26.377
And it has a category of cats.

47
00:02:26.377 --> 00:02:30.834
And that's because Joey and I know
that Joey is the author of this file,

48
00:02:30.834 --> 00:02:35.200
because it says so
right there that Joey authored this file.

49
00:02:35.200 --> 00:02:38.650
Well it also has that, Vaughn Smith
is also the author on here, so

50
00:02:38.650 --> 00:02:40.720
there's two authors.

51
00:02:40.720 --> 00:02:44.530
There's nothing about Vaughn or
Joey anywhere in this file,

52
00:02:44.530 --> 00:02:47.750
well Joey was on the title slide,
but Vaughn wasn't in there.

53
00:02:47.750 --> 00:02:52.000
It didn't tell me anything about Fuego or
Bishop from the very beginning, so this is

54
00:02:52.000 --> 00:02:58.010
all that information that can be stored
with the file, to help you catalog it.

55
00:02:58.010 --> 00:03:01.610
It's kind of like if
you're using your context,

56
00:03:01.610 --> 00:03:06.280
there's a lot of fields when you have your
first name, last name, the organization,

57
00:03:06.280 --> 00:03:09.220
the birthday, there's all sort of
different fields that you can add,

58
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:12.660
to be able to just keep on adding
information to know what this is about.

59
00:03:12.660 --> 00:03:13.680
It's kind of like that,

60
00:03:13.680 --> 00:03:19.470
it's like extending your contact
information within this file.

61
00:03:19.470 --> 00:03:21.520
And these are all things
that can be edited.

62
00:03:21.520 --> 00:03:26.300
Now this came over already created,
because Joey went ahead and

63
00:03:26.300 --> 00:03:29.130
put that into this document.

64
00:03:29.130 --> 00:03:30.438
Really I was the one who put it into that.

The words or the letters that are in for

519
00:27:06.610 --> 00:27:09.740

00:27:13.631 --> 00:27:14.138

00:28:01.755 --> 00:28:05.451

547
00:28:12.790 --> 00:28:15.980
And you could add a digital
signature to this document.

548
00:28:15.980 --> 00:28:21.260
The whole idea about adding
a digital signature is saying that,

549
00:28:21.260 --> 00:28:25.430
I am signing off on this and
I'm attaching my signature to it.

550
00:28:25.430 --> 00:28:29.060
And that indicates that I was
the last person that touched it.

551
00:28:29.060 --> 00:28:34.700
And then if I send it to Mike, if somebody
had compromised it in between that time,

552
00:28:34.700 --> 00:28:37.980
then that digital signature
would no longer be valid.

553
00:28:37.980 --> 00:28:41.740
And then it would indicate that
somebody else has messed with the file,

554
00:28:41.740 --> 00:28:42.500
if you wanna say.

555
00:28:42.500 --> 00:28:46.990
So it's just that extra level of
security of understanding that is,

556
00:28:46.990 --> 00:28:51.800
I signed off on this, I created this,
I edited it, and I'm done.

557
00:28:51.800 --> 00:28:55.390
And so if it's broken,
then somebody's tampered with it.

558
00:28:55.390 --> 00:28:56.908
And we don't necessarily want that.

559
00:28:56.908 --> 00:29:03.010
And you do have to have a certificate
that validates your digital signature.

560
00:29:03.010 --> 00:29:06.333
And that's, again, a lot of times
if you're in a large organization,

561
00:29:06.333 --> 00:29:09.834
your company will issue a certificate for
you or have a certificate server.

562
00:29:09.834 --> 00:29:13.892
And everything that's set up within your
organization that basically verifies that

563
00:29:13.892 --> 00:29:16.610
Vonne has signed this,
this is Vonne, and we're done.

564
00:29:16.610 --> 00:29:17.950

00:29:17.950 --> 00:29:21.551

566
00:29:21.551 --> 00:29:26.367
But for use around the office or,
in a lot of times, in a normal capacity,

567
00:29:26.367 --> 00:29:31.740
you probably won't need to go to this

568
00:29:31.740 --> 00:29:37.020
But it is available, and in huge
organizations this can be really important

569
